BEGIN NOW AUTHORS NOTE SHANGRI LA AND THEO JAMES : An Intro concerning the origins of the Author END
BEGIN NOW We were all born in a little town called Shangri La California.  END
BEGIN NOW Unaware of our incapacity to age, we treated ourselves like mortals, eventually convincing ourselves and thus transforming ourselves.  END
BEGIN NOW Some found this result in travels, others in stationary trending.  END
BEGIN NOW Something keeps them, us; from realizing and accepting.  END
BEGIN NOW This dark wet hesitance that lays on our gumption like a lead vest. END
BEGIN NOW Theo James spent years teaching us his logics on the redwood deck and under the covered bridge.  END
BEGIN NOW He was always around and ready to explain just why it was we weren't allowed to say certain words or sing certain songs.  END
BEGIN NOW "This is the Age of Appearance.  END
BEGIN NOW We have become aware of the literal application of human programming, and have tied it directly to superficial expression, thus presentation supplants reality." He spoke often of ages, and often spoke on the concept of ages.  END
BEGIN NOW "An Age lasts as long as a generation.  END
BEGIN NOW between the time you're born and the time you make a baby is a generation.  END
BEGIN NOW See, an Age only lasts until it's replaced, but there are always a series of Ages occurring at once, and it can be said that all previous Ages that have occurred are now happening simultaneously, and any new Age only adds to the din.  END
BEGIN NOW This continues until we take a dimensional shift and accept all Ages as occurring simultaneously, which will complicate our theory of time and various other seemingly transparent matters."  END
BEGIN NOW We were too young to get most of it.  END
BEGIN NOW fourteen, sixteen, eighteen.  END
BEGIN NOW Even at twenty, we still just kept him near as a side kick eccentric, and never as a great teacher.  END
BEGIN NOW Maybe that was intentional though.  END
BEGIN NOW He said all truth comes in the form of punch lines, but he wasn't that funny, which kind of suggests that he was full of shit.  END
BEGIN NOW But his favorite underdog is the failed inventor, finding thousands of new and unexpected ways to not quite do what he was hoping.  END
BEGIN NOW Failure is just a negative expression of discovery.  END
BEGIN NOW "Not to say that all discovery is positive.  END
BEGIN NOW Quite the opposite.  END
BEGIN NOW Choosing your realm mode and style of discovery is vital to maintaining a positive self perpetuating pattern." END
BEGIN NOW I refuse to describe him, because you would stop listening.  END
BEGIN NOW You would shrug off his input as obscene and absurd.  END
BEGIN NOW You would condemn him based on an incapacity to integrate.  END
BEGIN NOW "Ennit funny how I'm the one who can't seem to integrate, but I'm the only one who's still friends with everybody? How is that not integrating? That's better than integrating.  END
BEGIN NOW It's assimilation." The town loved him, but hated all that he stood for, and he could never hold clear how he felt about the town.  END
BEGIN NOW Sweet mad Shangri la California, No duplicate exists in all the realms of all the mythologies of evermore.  END
BEGIN NOW Nowhere else are all the girls cursed to live betwixt some sort of forest nymph fairy experience of the sprawling redwood womb of these woods.  END
BEGIN NOW Nowhere else do the young men go mad and run screaming up and down the streets in search of the demon that's taken hold of their boot strings.  END
BEGIN NOW One man lives on the hill.  END
BEGIN NOW He paces his sandstone ridge and digs worry lines with his feet, deep enough for the satellites to see.  END
BEGIN NOW He does not remember why he left, or what he hoped to find.  END
BEGIN NOW All he remembers is why it's not safe down there in the town. END
BEGIN NOW Another man lives in a hole by the river.  END
BEGIN NOW He whistles at night to call spirits to him, hoping they'll tell him stories darker than his.  END
BEGIN NOW He doesn't remember when he fell away, or why he would want to be any other way, but he knows more than he's willing to hold, and looks for ways to loosen it.  END
BEGIN NOW Sweet mad Shangri La California, mother of chaotic children of fury, lost in the mourning of moments unhinging.  END
BEGIN NOW He stabbed Melvin here, thirteen years ago today.  END
BEGIN NOW Don't look at the date.  END
BEGIN NOW It's not your birthday anymore.  END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps that's the line you're looking for.  END
BEGIN NOW It's no longer a magical holiday.  END
BEGIN NOW The fairies are gone, and the demons now play.  END
BEGIN NOW In the tilted the falling the whim of the way.  END
BEGIN NOW We battle the burgeoning depths of decay, send innocence stumbling back on her way. END

BEGIN NOW softly tightly in secret queit pauses, hiding the raw depth of raw.  END

BEGIN NOW INTRODUCTION TO THE WRITING STYLE OR LACK THEREOF END
BEGIN NOW There once was a time when I'd fly off the handle and run to my notebook to scramble down thoughts.  END
BEGIN NOW There once was a time when that's all that I wanted, that's all that I sought in my daily onslaught of wandering whatnot.  END
BEGIN NOW At a certain point i forgot what I wanted.  END
BEGIN NOW My notes became clouded and scrambled.  END
BEGIN NOW One note sends me through thick heavy words of past masters, reminding me of my capacities to speak intellectually to the up and ups, the educated, the echelon.  END
BEGIN NOW Another note pulls me towards awareness, not tied to the patterns and myths of society, not caught in the rat trap of repitition, rather baiting my subconscious so as to launch it off into realms unknown in hopes of bringing back thoughts of worth. END
BEGIN NOW I used to listen to strangers talk on the bus and jot down their conversations, no matter how bland and empty.  END
BEGIN NOW Simply tracking the interaction of strangers, my third role permanizing the occurence for all time.  END
BEGIN NOW What do I do now? I look at the words on the page and gauge my connection to them and their capacity to reflect that which is.  END
BEGIN NOW The expressive loop lacks the flesh of literal experience, and the author is forced to throw in some sort of actual occurrence to bring the reader back to something that actually exists apart from language. END
BEGIN NOW This is a very specific intro written by a writer who claims not to write, and yet he writes daily.  END
BEGIN NOW He jots down and struggles with cover letters and business plans and project management logics, but his words are no longer the feather spark fliers that waltz across the sky and burn the eyes of every unwitting passerby.  END
BEGIN NOW He has quit every project he started, calling them off with a vague "post-poned!" unwilling to accept anything as disowned.  END
BEGIN NOW But this is a moment of realism.  END
BEGIN NOW A moment frozen in time.  END
BEGIN NOW This is now and post-poned means dead, abandoned, and irrelevant.  END
BEGIN NOW The development of past projects can be justified as partial projects aimed at developing project capacities, and this to a certain extent is true, but competion and release are the things that have kept the author frozen in this loop of managerial ramblings.  END
BEGIN NOW He's trying.  END
BEGIN NOW He really is.  END
BEGIN NOW He's always known how to start.  END
BEGIN NOW You sit down, get excited, follow the flow and don't bother crossing your eyes, but dotting your t's is fine.  END
BEGIN NOW Manifest.  END
BEGIN NOW Manifest with zest gusto gumption and puzaz.  END
BEGIN NOW We are not tracing delicate veins here.  END
BEGIN NOW We are not slicing open the mucose membrane of the mylean sheath to see the literal pathways of thought, rather we are throwing our subconscious out of a plane and letting it scream its dying words as it hurtles earthward.  END
BEGIN NOW We are bringing ourselves into a mental picture that we convince ourselves is real to prompt what possible reaction we might have to such a thing.  END
BEGIN NOW Last visit home I read the paper and saw that an old man had died falling off a cliff that overlooked the river above a bridge by a certain hairpin curve.  END
BEGIN NOW I pondered the thought and found myself there 10 years prior.  END
BEGIN NOW "I been there!" I said to my dad.  END
BEGIN NOW "I climbed that cliff, and almost fell. Almost died like he did!" Seemingly meaningless drivel.  END
BEGIN NOW   END
BEGIN NOW His moment of death was preceded ten years by my moment on that same cliff side, sliding and frantically clinging to tiny seedling trees, unsure for the first time ever, whether I'd make it.  END
BEGIN NOW Just another tiny meaningless trigger tracing paths and possibilities as occurrences continue to accrue along the infinite stretching tongue of paper our pens play across, skidding along, hesitant to stop, for in stagnation is death and the sliding earth beneath us brings us closer to the cliff by the bridge overlooking a certain hairpin curve.  END

BEGIN NOW My dad swears.  END
BEGIN NOW He says that when he talks about his paycheck.  END
BEGIN NOW You don’t seem like twenny.  END
BEGIN NOW You seem like a kid.” END
BEGIN NOW “Thanks Charlie.” It felt good hearing him say that.  END
BEGIN NOW Like I had just received a pardon.  END
BEGIN NOW “You like being a kid?” He picked at the plastic covering the chain of his swing, pondering my query. END
BEGIN NOW “Yeah.  END
BEGIN NOW I like being a kid.  END
BEGIN NOW Grown ups are all super worried, and usually about jobs, and money.  END
BEGIN NOW My only job is to collect snails in the garden, and I get a penny a snail.  END
BEGIN NOW They eat the plants.  END
BEGIN NOW Yeah, being a kid is good.  END
BEGIN NOW My dad is always tired ‘cause he has a job.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t wanna be tired all the time like that.” END
BEGIN NOW “Yeah, when I was a kid all my friends wanted to grow up.  END
BEGIN NOW They couldn’t wait for kindergarten, than they couldn’t wait for middle school, than they couldn’t wait for high school.  END
BEGIN NOW I knew this barefoot guy who was just always barefoot, and he told me about how humans get stuck in this repeated preparation cycle.” END
BEGIN NOW “Repeated prepration?” END
BEGIN NOW “Yeah.  END
BEGIN NOW You’re smart Charlie.  END
BEGIN NOW What, second grade? So you’re getting ready for third grade, and I’ll bet you can’t wait.  END
BEGIN NOW But the way this barefoot guy described it, everyone just keeps getting ready, waiting for the next thing.  END
BEGIN NOW Gotta be ready for high school, ‘cause that’s when things start happening.  END
BEGIN NOW Gotta be ready for college, ‘cause that decides your entire future.  END
BEGIN NOW Gotta be ready for your twenties, ‘cause you establish your permenant psychological patterns there.  END
BEGIN NOW Gotta be ready for your thirties, ‘cause you’ve passed your peak, and therefore it just gets dimmer and lamer from there.  END
BEGIN NOW Gotta be ready for your forties and fifties and make sure you have a nice plot of land for your burial, and visit it to make sure they aren’t burying people and then moving them years later to resell the same plot… woah.  END
BEGIN NOW Sorry Charlie.” END
BEGIN NOW “That’s alright.  END
BEGIN NOW I didn’t know what most of that meant.” END
BEGIN NOW “Oh.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, that’s good.  END
BEGIN NOW But see, I’m just … I dunno, when I was a kid I had some secret knowledge that no one else had. END
BEGIN NOW I could feel it slipping away. END
BEGIN NOW Just a child with my Charlie Brown lunchbox and beanie with a bobbin. END
BEGIN NOW Just a child with my three favorite fears. END
BEGIN NOW Strangers, the dark, and being alone. END
BEGIN NOW Popsicle stains, scraped knees, missing baby teeth. END
BEGIN NOW But I had something more.  END
BEGIN NOW A very special fear neglected by my childhood peers.  END
BEGIN NOW Age. END
BEGIN NOW Even at five I understood that I would one day die and be buried alone in the dark and be dead. END
BEGIN NOW What scared me were the times I couldn’t remember.  END
BEGIN NOW The days that melt together under the lazy summer sun to the point where a month can go by without barely a memory forged.  END
BEGIN NOW I felt that this was the ultimate wrong.  END
BEGIN NOW Letting our few precious moments slip by without grabbing a moment, a scar, a memory.  END
BEGIN NOW I tried to savor each moment with impulse and franticness, screaming from action to activity. END
BEGIN NOW They didn’t understand.  END
BEGIN NOW The grown ups, they still don’t.  END
BEGIN NOW Their priorities backwards.  END
BEGIN NOW Who has time for these mortals? Testing our knowledge of numbers and states.  END
BEGIN NOW Stupid Bastards! It’s late! Don’t you hear the bells chiming your swift life away? END
BEGIN NOW So I skipped all my homework, got by on my wits.  END
BEGIN NOW Spent weekends and after school trying to save all the precious few moments authority had left me to live my sweet childhood out it. END
BEGIN NOW And than it was gone.  END
BEGIN NOW All of a sudden I was a senior in High School.  END
BEGIN NOW A Sophmore in community college, morning drunk on a swing in the park, barking at a small blonde boy.  END
BEGIN NOW A senior at Cal, a stumbling hungover, out of the gas station into the sun... END
BEGIN NOW Chapter 3 BELLS    BERKELEY, 2008 END
BEGIN NOW The sun screams down at me, unhindered by my stupid tree.  END
BEGIN NOW I hear the bells KABONG begin to toll.  END
BEGIN NOW A slow chongy KABONG falls hollowly down.  END
BEGIN NOW KABONG I believe that’s three.  END
BEGIN NOW Although KABONG perhaps I missed the first one.  END
BEGIN NOW KABONG I think I heard the first one.  END
BEGIN NOW Which would make this KABONG six? So that means five left? Wait, what KABONG time is it? Alrite, it’s eleven, and that’s seven, unless I missed the first in which KABONG case that makes eight.  END
BEGIN NOW Or nine now.  END
BEGIN NOW KABONG And that would be ten, unless… why do I KABONG care to react so much? It’s the goddamn KABONG bell and nothing more.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m not late, but I’m all fidgety now, like I’m supposed to be somewhere.  END
BEGIN NOW The bells call me once more, begging me to approach the doors of the church from whence I once crawled to glorious empty freedom… END
BEGIN NOW I feel like I’m late.  END
BEGIN NOW Should I get to the library? No, that’s just my instinct, responding the the bells by approaching the church doors for service.  END
BEGIN NOW The church has been replaced by the towering beast of academia.  END
BEGIN NOW And thus we trade our addictions in for different yet identical direction. END
BEGIN NOW I did the math the other day.  END
BEGIN NOW I’ve been to over thirty five hundred church services.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s been a large part of life for quite awhile now.  END
BEGIN NOW Saints Peter and Paul Orthodox Church, been baptized and brought up inside its extended realm.  END
BEGIN NOW I never really questioned or doubted it.  END
BEGIN NOW Belief can sometimes exist the way people share a blanket.  END
BEGIN NOW But now I’m gone, finding my own warmth, mostly from my sweet glorious belly fire that blazes through all hours of the night. END
BEGIN NOW I never chose Orthodoxy.  END
BEGIN NOW I chose not to resist.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, I chose my battles as all angsty questioners will do.  END
BEGIN NOW I wasn’t a nodder.  END
BEGIN NOW I have the horrible habit of stopping people, and asking them why.  END
BEGIN NOW I see many nodders, still nodding away, sharing the beautiful tapestry blanket of belief, religion, and community.  END
BEGIN NOW Not all of them nodders.  END
BEGIN NOW Many talkers.  END
BEGIN NOW Many interested, many expanding, many understanding.  END
BEGIN NOW But I always, every Sunday, had to resist raising my hand during Homily, asking the pontificating priest, “How can finite actions have infinite consequences?” END
BEGIN NOW Even after the sun has gone down, it’s light outside for at least an hour.  END
BEGIN NOW The world is bluish and dim.  END
BEGIN NOW You go in to take a leak, and when you return, it’s black.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s when it feels sudden.  END
BEGIN NOW My excitement and joy for being Christian had long since set, and I wandered through my last bit of high school, and into Junior College in a bluish haze.  END
BEGIN NOW  Then one day I turned around and it was pitch black. END
BEGIN NOW I slouch into the classroom as the teacher starts to talk.  END
BEGIN NOW I puddle into my chair, tossle my hair back out of place, and feel my energy drain like paint dripping down my face.  END
BEGIN NOW I feel like a fraud.  END
BEGIN NOW Flaunting something I obviously don’t have, didn’t know the reading, don’t know what’s due… I hide behind bad hygiene as a way to avoid a relationship.  END
BEGIN NOW My insomnia and supposed craziness, just ways to delay obligation.  END
BEGIN NOW And my ramblings.  END
BEGIN NOW They do nothing.  END
BEGIN NOW And all too much darkening.  END
BEGIN NOW And the teacher drones on… “Harriet Beecher Mutha Fuckin Stowe, Ya’ll!” All I can do is curl forward and try to ignore this guy. END
BEGIN NOW The margins of my notes… I don’t have notes.  END
BEGIN NOW My notes are made up of doodle faces that gaze back with quirky grins, like they know something dark and morbidly hilarious.  END
BEGIN NOW And I’ve drawn it so many times, it’s been driven deep into the rock wall of my mind.  END
BEGIN NOW And now, I see face3s.  END
BEGIN NOW Ones I’ve drawn before.  END
BEGIN NOW When I close my eyes.  END
BEGIN NOW In sloppy scribbling intensity.  END
BEGIN NOW I seem to be trailing off again…   And suddenly it’s done.  END
BEGIN NOW Books slap closed, zips and shuffles, and we all gush out the doors as one.  END
BEGIN NOW I quickly find a spot off to the side to catch my breath with some tobacco burnings. END
BEGIN NOW I find a tree near Sproul Plaza, on the lawn.  END
BEGIN NOW A detatched spot to observe the motion.  END
BEGIN NOW The movements of… Them.  END
BEGIN NOW All those passing people who seem to know where they’re going.  END
BEGIN NOW I crouch beneath my tree, light a grit, and scribble down some more meaningless shit… END
BEGIN NOW “I chose this tree because it seemed like the right tree for me to crouch beneath and collect my thoughts as the cute blonde from class walks past.” And I squat there as she passes, holding my hangover before me as my reason for not speaking.  END
BEGIN NOW Even though she lingers, glancing at me.  END
BEGIN NOW And as she passes I notice her pants are staring at me.  END
BEGIN NOW Especially the butt.  END
BEGIN NOW The key is to look busy.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s why I doodle.  END
BEGIN NOW And write.  END
BEGIN NOW And play guitar.  END
BEGIN NOW And pop my knuckles and chew my fingernails and find little toys to play with.  END
BEGIN NOW Pebbles to make patterns.  END
BEGIN NOW Sticks to draw in the dirt.  END
BEGIN NOW Rocks to carve into each other.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m occupied.  END
BEGIN NOW Like a restroom.  END
BEGIN NOW Or a seat on the bus.  END
BEGIN NOW My attention is taken.  END
BEGIN NOW Earn it.  END
BEGIN NOW Why must I encroach? Come interrupt me.  END
BEGIN NOW Or leave me be.  END
BEGIN NOW Don’t just glance over expectantly. END
BEGIN NOW I chose this tree because it called to me, and I needed a moment of peace.  END
BEGIN NOW Creation.  END
BEGIN NOW Distraction.  END
BEGIN NOW At times the world comes at me in descriptive paragraphs and I need the elongated pause to recover from the onslaught of experience.  END
BEGIN NOW I didn’t stop to watch the cute blonde from class walk past.  END
BEGIN NOW She has a yellow headband and black silk pants.  END
BEGIN NOW I quickly name her Marie, and decide that one day she’ll marry me.  END

BEGIN NOW Ah yes, the curse of beauty.  END
BEGIN NOW The common people are far too intrigued to approach thee, Sweet Marie.  END

BEGIN NOW Sproul Plaza is… Crawling and seething and flyering and screaming.  END
BEGIN NOW And all beneath those silly fuckin trees.  END
BEGIN NOW Invented right here on campus.  END
BEGIN NOW I hate those fuckin trees.  END
BEGIN NOW They’re an existential mockery of what we choose to do with our potential.  END
BEGIN NOW Like absurdist chess pieces, or solders at a wedding, they line the wide path that is Sproul plaza, leading from Telegraph to Sather Gate, under which we find our hero, lying on his back.  END
BEGIN NOW No, not me.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m off to the side, under my hallowed tree.  END
BEGIN NOW Our hero is… END
BEGIN NOW Cyco.  END
BEGIN NOW (pronounced Psy-Ko) Or, the upside down cycler.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s doing his art routine.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s hard to explain.  END
BEGIN NOW He has a lot of props; an upside down bike, modified in such a way so that he can lay beneath it and peddle… an invisible rope which he climbs, hoping to get to heaven.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s usually got jammies or a hospital gown on, to which he pins many little painted pieces of paper.  END
BEGIN NOW He has ann umbrella, wildly painted.  END
BEGIN NOW A blanket.  END
BEGIN NOW A towel or two.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s always in the midst of a nonsensical display of true art for art’s sake.  END
BEGIN NOW Swimming in place, or the ritualistic crossing and uncrossing of sticks.  END
BEGIN NOW Or just climbing his invisible rope.  END
BEGIN NOW Pilot goggles.  END
BEGIN NOW Always pilot goggles.  END
BEGIN NOW Almost forgot about that.  END
BEGIN NOW He wears ‘em so often you start to think they’re just his eyes.  END
BEGIN NOW Everyone knows that.  END
BEGIN NOW Don’t need to mention his pilot goggle eyes.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s a given. END
BEGIN NOW Today he’s lying on the ground, pawing at the sky, as if he’s swimming, except more floundering, or treading water.  END
BEGIN NOW Maybe it’s the backfloat.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s got his head under a towel, only his mouth is showing.  END
BEGIN NOW An Asian girl pauses and bends towards him.  END
BEGIN NOW His displaced mouth has a slight grin.  END
BEGIN NOW The Asian girl is extremely perplexed.  END
BEGIN NOW Worried too. END
BEGIN NOW “Excuse me, sir?” She bends towards him, clutching her books to her chest like a bullet proof vest.  END
BEGIN NOW “Sir? Do you need help?” He shakes his head slowly, and swims languidly on through the concrete.  END
BEGIN NOW “Sir?” She obviously didn’t notice him shake his head.  END
BEGIN NOW Or maybe she doesn’t trust his judgment.  END
BEGIN NOW She seems absurd.  END
BEGIN NOW A caring stone in the midst of the roaring flowing crowd.  END
BEGIN NOW Even the cycler just smiles, and swims on through it. END
BEGIN NOW She looks up and down the stream of people, looking for something to reassure her.  END
BEGIN NOW A white passer by quickly fills her in; “He always does that.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s his art.  END
BEGIN NOW Don’t get too close, I hear he has rabies.” The Asian girl hurries on, not looking back and the young white guppie swims up the stream after her.  END
BEGIN NOW For a moment he stops and glances back at the cycler, thinking to himself, END
BEGIN NOW He seems pretty happy with himself.  END
BEGIN NOW I wonder if he’s gonna go to heaven for being innocent or hell for being crazy- END
BEGIN NOW Under my tree, I sit and watch, more caught by the people who interact with him, than by the actual hero.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s alright.  END
BEGIN NOW Some memorable lines.  END
BEGIN NOW Once I was clipped by a passing bit of conversation he was spitting.  END
BEGIN NOW A polite student, a nodder, was standing there nodding.  END
BEGIN NOW I almost approached so as to take part in the exchange, but I thought better of it, and sat nearby, so as to overhear. END
BEGIN NOW “The Future is very shakey…” He held his hands out, with the invisible world between them, and he shook it for dramatic effect.  END
BEGIN NOW  “Because it doesn’t exist…” And he pet his invisible cat, and nodded, staring straight into the nodder’s eyes, who stood there nodding back, like a hypnotized pigeon. END
BEGIN NOW I liked it so much I turned it into a poem.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s called… END
BEGIN NOW In Which the Upside-Down Cycler Confronts The Existential Crisis by Providing us with an Example of Action without Meaning, meanwhile paralleling this very action with the question of the Existence of Time END
BEGIN NOW and it goes like this… END
BEGIN NOW The Future is very Shakey,Because it Don’t exist… END
BEGIN NOW Now the key to this piece is the dot dot dot at the end.  END
BEGIN NOW The ampersand.  END
BEGIN NOW Because the poem isn’t over.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s still existing and being experienced, simply because it echoes in your skull cavern, and therefore it can’t end.  END
BEGIN NOW The ampersands of time.  END
BEGIN NOW Such are the days of our lives. END
BEGIN NOW I think I’ve hit another brick wall. END
BEGIN NOW While I’m dribbling out all this nonsense as a way to purge my severely hungover brain, two young black guys approach the upside down cycler.  END
BEGIN NOW They get right up next to him, and point and laugh, enjoying the spectacle.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s not in a degrading sort of way.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, not really.  END
BEGIN NOW The cycler doesn’t seem to mind.  END
BEGIN NOW I hear them talk to him.  END
BEGIN NOW Something like “Man, you fuckin crazy!” “Yeah, what the fuck!” One slaps a knee, and they both cackle.  END
BEGIN NOW This response seems the most fitting.  END
BEGIN NOW Yes.  END
BEGIN NOW This man is hilarious.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s not normal.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s not a threat to himself or others.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s just kinda fuckin hilarious. END
BEGIN NOW And for half a second he represents everything.  END
BEGIN NOW A moment of frantic action with no context, no meaning, no reason.  END
BEGIN NOW He is the ever present essence of existence.  END
BEGIN NOW Why are we here? Because what the fuck else are we gonna do? All action is meaningless without explanation.  END
BEGIN NOW Meaining becomes clouded and lost in language.  END
BEGIN NOW Excessive abstraction alienates the spectator, while a lack therof leaves the spectator swimming in concrete.  END
BEGIN NOW What in God’s name am I saying? I… I can’t follow my own train of thought.  END
BEGIN NOW I need to calm down.  END
BEGIN NOW I need to stop watching this guy.  END
BEGIN NOW Maybe his madness is catching… END
BEGIN NOW I find a spot by the fountain.  END
BEGIN NOW A spot to sit and space out.  END
BEGIN NOW This fountain.  END
BEGIN NOW Filled with bubbles, stupid college cliché.  END
BEGIN NOW I guess everyone gets to do it once.  END
BEGIN NOW Or what if the university does it ‘cause that’s how they clean it.  END
BEGIN NOW Keep out the mold and shit.  END
BEGIN NOW Stupid bubbles.  END
BEGIN NOW The sound of the fountain slowly crushes all my thoughts, and I’m lost in white noise.  END
BEGIN NOW My mind floats on a clear gray lake.  END
BEGIN NOW Within the sound is a waterfall.  END
BEGIN NOW A very specific waterfall.  END
BEGIN NOW It drops from my mind into my chest.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s the waterfall we used to jump from in Big Sur.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s almost dry now.  END
BEGIN NOW This jump is no longer safe, seeing as the landing spot is ankle deep now.  END
BEGIN NOW Some shift in the rivers flow, a logjam up stream, a gush of silt and sand, filling up the gorge swimhole.  END
BEGIN NOW But once and forever more in my mind, from the Big Sur cliffs we’d launch out and fall, thirty forty fifty feet down into the deep gorge waters. END
BEGIN NOW CHAPTER 4  Big Sur, CA1998 END
BEGIN NOW Big Sur is a campground a couple hours south of Feugit.  END
BEGIN NOW We’ve camped there every summer since I can remember with the same twenty or so families from the church, every year.  END
BEGIN NOW We transplant almost the entire block.  END
BEGIN NOW Several blocks.  END
BEGIN NOW There were over 500 people in our church, and maybe 6000 people in Feugit.  END
BEGIN NOW That means we were almost a tenth of the Feugit population.  END
BEGIN NOW Wow.  END
BEGIN NOW Never did that math before.  END
BEGIN NOW Weird. END
BEGIN NOW So we’re at Big Sur, with this church community extension.  END
BEGIN NOW And it’s the network of campsites, so we have this huge stomping ground.  END
BEGIN NOW Stop in at the Johnsons and try their blackened salmon.  END
BEGIN NOW At the Patzke’s site they’re serving up fried crawdad.  END
BEGIN NOW One year we caught a gopher snake, and Mister Scheopp killed and cooked it for us. END
BEGIN NOW So it felt like we were still in Ben Lomond, like the walls and protective environment of community was still there.  END
BEGIN NOW It musta been the summer between seventh and eighth grade.  END
BEGIN NOW We were on break.  END
BEGIN NOW And here, in the woods, a bunch of scrappy redneck kids, we were immortal.  END
BEGIN NOW At night we’d still be subject to the minor requirements of our parents.  END
BEGIN NOW “No more cigars! You already had one tonight!” … “No, you can’t go hiking.  END
BEGIN NOW You’re just gonna go smoke cigars.” “What do you mean camp on the ridge?!! What do you think we got this campsite for?! No! No camping on the ridge, no night hiking, and no cigars!” END
BEGIN NOW But two or three miles upriver, the silence of nature overwhelms, and even the thought of parental disappointment melts away under the crushing sound of water.  END
BEGIN NOW We’re at the gorge.  END
BEGIN NOW The only approval we need is from each other.  END
BEGIN NOW I pull a backwood cigar and a lighter from their safe stowage of plastic baggy.  END
BEGIN NOW Eli and JP approve.  END
BEGIN NOW We light the cigar, lay back on the rock, and continue to do as little as possible. END
BEGIN NOW The massive slab of obsidian has been soaking up heat since sunrise.  END
BEGIN NOW Now, six hours later, our bodies sprawl out, soaking in the sun, baked by the stinging heat, leaving wet body prints on the rock when we shift, or get up to jump off the rock, ten feet down into the icy shock-water. END
BEGIN NOW Most of the campsites in Big Sur are canopied by the looming redwoods.  END
BEGIN NOW The sun leaking through makes birthmark light-splotches in the shady hall of nature. END
BEGIN NOW There’s really not much to do at the campsite.  END
BEGIN NOW The housewives talk.  END
BEGIN NOW The kids scramble around, find sticks to use as scepters and rocks to use as rubies.  END
BEGIN NOW Most make a voyage to the river at some point.  END
BEGIN NOW Not a huge river.  END
BEGIN NOW At some points you have to swim, at others you can dance across on rocks, from one shore to the other, like footprints on the floor for dance lessons. END
BEGIN NOW The river is inhabited by crawdads, which we often catch and eat.  END
BEGIN NOW I remember walking with my dad and getting bit by one for the first time.  END
BEGIN NOW Just a warning snap from it’s cray pincers.  END
BEGIN NOW “There’s something in the water! It Bit me!!” I hollered, crawling up my dad’s leg, trying to get out of the water.  END
BEGIN NOW I was five at the time. END
BEGIN NOW “Oh, it’s probably a baby crocodile.” END
BEGIN NOW “There are crocodiles here?” END
BEGIN NOW “Yup.  END
BEGIN NOW Just watch out for the big ones.” My dad always liked to mess with our minds.  END
BEGIN NOW I think maybe my problem is I’m still trying to sort through what’s real and what’s not.  END
BEGIN NOW You know, banana slug goo will melt your hands off if you don’t wash it quick enough? And you have to wash it off with hot sauce.  END
BEGIN NOW And if your hands start burning, that means they’re starting to melt, and you need more hot sauce before it’s too late… END
BEGIN NOW As you hike further up the river away from the campsites, cliff faces rise up on either side.  END
BEGIN NOW Massive boulders are strewn about causing dwarven waterfalls and liliputian bays.  END
BEGIN NOW A couple miles upriver is the gorge.  END
BEGIN NOW The gorge is just about the deepest point in the river.  END
BEGIN NOW At least that I know of.After a wet winter, it can be over twenty feet deep, but it’s usually between ten and fifteen.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s also the point where the river cuts right along the bottom of the cliff that follows the river at a distance.  END
BEGIN NOW A log leans diagonally going twenty or thirty feet up this cliff.  END
BEGIN NOW This is what substitutes as a stairwell.  END
BEGIN NOW There are several ledges reachable from the log.  END
BEGIN NOW A rope hangs from the tree.  END
BEGIN NOW Level one is fifteen feet up.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s where you grab the bottom of the rope and swing out, letting go before you swing back in and smoosh yourself.  END
BEGIN NOW Level two is maybe twenty five feet up, and you have access to the rope, but most people just jump out.  END
BEGIN NOW The rope hangs from the tree, which I guess is level three.  END
BEGIN NOW I saw some kid hang from the tree and drop, but I jumped from level four, which is even higher.  END
BEGIN NOW You have to jump over the tree.  END
BEGIN NOW From up there the crags and cliff faces reach out towards your landing spot.  END
BEGIN NOW For most, this is the only cliff.  END
BEGIN NOW The one you can jump off of, and try to count, but you can’t get past two, ‘cause it’s “One one thousand, Two one thousa… Holy fuck! Holy fuck! Holy fuuuuuu…” Before you’re interrupted by the water enveloping you, leaving your heels bright red and electrically numb. END
BEGIN NOW On a bad day you’ll get to the gorge and find naked hippies taking pictures of each other.  END
BEGIN NOW On a fine day you’ll find it fairly deserted, almost reserved for you and your posse to horse around.  END
BEGIN NOW On a good day, there will be grown ups and there will be beer.  END
BEGIN NOW At least in their stomachs.  END
BEGIN NOW And there will be rednecks having flashbacks to their teenage years.  END
BEGIN NOW I can still see them, all drunk, open Coors in hand, scaling the cliff, reaching the top, and trying to muster a double gainer.  END
BEGIN NOW A crowd spreads across the rocks, chanting “Jump! Jump! Jump! Jump!” He inches towards the ledge, scans the crowds, catches every cute chick’s eye, takes a final chug, and finally pushes himself off into the air, END
BEGIN NOW hurtling, it’s a half gainer… a little farther, it’s a full one… another half, almost there, but you can see he’s gonna land wrong.  END
BEGIN NOW You wanna close your eyes, look away, but you watch as *SMACK* like a bird hitting a window.  END
BEGIN NOW Any other landing besides feel first or diving, the sound is a thick raw slap.  END
BEGIN NOW A hunk of liver on a marble floor.  END
BEGIN NOW Watching him crawl out of the shallows, his torso pinker than his sunburned back… it makes your own torso tingle just under the skin, a flashback to misfired flips ending in similar fashion. END
BEGIN NOW This particular year, I was, what, twelve? Thirteen? Anyways.  END
BEGIN NOW We lay on this rock, basking and drying, leaving our wet spots.  END
BEGIN NOW Every few minutes we’d crack an eyelid and watch a body hurtle downwards, usually accompanied by a loudly screamed profanity.  END
BEGIN NOW Quality entertainment.  END
BEGIN NOW This is the ritual.  END
BEGIN NOW Fairly common, I suppose.  END
BEGIN NOW To lay in the sun until all the energy is fried and sucked out of your bodies, than flopping off the rock into the river, the crisp freezing water.  END
BEGIN NOW Soothes the burning body like nothing else.  END
BEGIN NOW I was about to flop into the water like a dead burnt fish when JP jumped up. END
BEGIN NOW “Who’s jumpin with me!?!” You could hear the frantic stretching edge in his voice, trying to sound hyped up, but unable to completely mask his terror.  END
BEGIN NOW Yup, he meant the big cliff.  END
BEGIN NOW I cracked an eye and looked at him. END
BEGIN NOW JP was the fat kid.  END
BEGIN NOW He wasn’t huge.  END
BEGIN NOW And since then he’s turned it around and become a ball of testosterone soaked muscle.  END
BEGIN NOW But back than at about one thirty, he pudged out like nothing standing next to us ninety pounders.  END
BEGIN NOW He was the guy at the back of the pack when we ran.  END
BEGIN NOW I was back there with him ‘cause I hated running.  END
BEGIN NOW He was always at the bottom of the dog pile, which was perfect.  END
BEGIN NOW Something soft to land on if your elbow drop victim dodges.  END
BEGIN NOW He was always at the bottom of the tree when we climbed.  END
BEGIN NOW Not the very bottom, but we never thought it safe for him to come all the way to the top where the trunk is as thick as your wrist and the branches are as thin as your fingers.  END
BEGIN NOW Oh, and he was the nicest guy on the planet.  END
BEGIN NOW Still is as far as I know.  END
BEGIN NOW But he’d never outdone me.  END
BEGIN NOW I could run faster, jump higher, dive deeper, and brag longer than he ever could.  END
BEGIN NOW And now, here he is, standing up, about to hurl himself from the highest cliff in the universe, into the water, with full knowledge that I’m too scared to.  END
BEGIN NOW What an asshole.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m the outdoer.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s the outdone.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, now, that’s not true at all.  END
BEGIN NOW But back than it was. END
BEGIN NOW I watched in stupefied wonder as he and, who was it? Jeff maybe? Eli? Or maybe it was Rachel.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, the two of them got up, and cheered at each other for a moment before heading off to scale the cliff.  END
BEGIN NOW Strange urges to scale after them arose in me, but I wasn’t gonna give in to the mad whim for at least another year.  END
BEGIN NOW I looked up at JP perched atop the cliff peeking over the edge, his eyes big and goggled.  END
BEGIN NOW He stepped back and my heart slowed. END
BEGIN NOW “Man,” I said to no one, “I knew he’d wimp out.” But then all at once, as if some pulley had snapped in his brain, he ran towards the edge and hurtled himself off.  END

BEGIN NOW SONG END
BEGIN NOW Your eyes are not like tropical oceans reflecting a sunset.  END
BEGIN NOW Nor are they eyes of tired exploding suns.  END
BEGIN NOW They shall not be referred to as "sapphire shining" or "the well my soul flounder in." Your eyes are not the spot I crawl inside when I cry.  END
BEGIN NOW Nor are they windows into the sky.  END
BEGIN NOW Any and all references to your eyes are hereby reduced to the formal, "blue" or the semi-formal, "nice." END
BEGIN NOW strict adherence to these aforementioned items, while not being mandatory or enforced, is highly encouraged, and will be rewarded with a comfortable distance from the emotions that the we of the world remain oh so baffled by.  END
BEGIN NOW In the event that the author becomes half-assed in his strictly platonic approach, the proper authorities will be notified, and the author will be exposed to unpleasant stimuli in order to deter him from repeating any behavior that might cause his eyes to become "starry" or "Bright" or any other unrealistic adjective meant to cause shimmering and quivering.  END
BEGIN NOW There shall be no shimmering and quivering.  END
BEGIN NOW There shall be no references to limpid pools, nor the sun, oceans or sky.  END
BEGIN NOW I have very little poetry these days.  END
BEGIN NOW I have no romantic notions or optimistic shimmer.  END
BEGIN NOW I have no concept of poetics.  END
BEGIN NOW No rumbling diatribe hiding behind my eyes.  END
BEGIN NOW My eyes are as dead and passive as they seem.  END
BEGIN NOW I have a hard time talking when you're around because I don't actually think about emotions any more.  END
BEGIN NOW Let me show to you the extent of my emotional capabilities:  END
BEGIN NOW "Music is pleasing.  END
BEGIN NOW Work is not.  END
BEGIN NOW Booze and pot are nice.  END
BEGIN NOW Sleep is the best." END
BEGIN NOW I'm not sure what happened.  END
BEGIN NOW I guess I may have closed off. END
BEGIN NOW It's this rambling sort of wander through your day, finding specifics that really capture something.  END
BEGIN NOW Anything.  END
BEGIN NOW Like how the upside down cycler seems to embody everything for a second.  END
BEGIN NOW There are little details throughout the day that do that to you.  END
BEGIN NOW But they're secret details saved special for you.  END
BEGIN NOW And if the main goal is simply moving between these magic details, than plot is totally unnecisarry.  END
BEGIN NOW Plot, in fact, gives an unrealistic illusion of movement and destination.  END

BEGIN NOW ACCIDENTAL GRADUATE END
BEGIN NOW I graduated accidentally, because my rambling just happened to coincide with what the major required of me.  END
BEGIN NOW What my degree got me was the ability to aim my ramble towards what my audience might be hoping to hear.  END
BEGIN NOW This is how I accidentally became a cook, a local news reporter for a town I had never been to, and now property manager for a half house half squat.  END
BEGIN NOW It's all just a rambling bluff, half hoping my words might click a switch somewhere and unlock the large stone door. END
BEGIN NOW So my degree has taught me to dismantle all aspects of reality until society is nothing more than a game of interdependent grinning, and my voice is nothing more than the sum total pendulum swing back from my father's view towards my grandfather's, but on a different plane, towards a twelve piece cycle circling around and dripping down your spine.  END
BEGIN NOW God, what am I talking about? What my English degree has got me.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, the ability to sound deep.  END
BEGIN NOW The pomposity to write as if I'm talking to you, the whim of ambient ramblistic tappings into subconscious apophenic patterns, but really it's all just flashing lights.  END
BEGIN NOW I feel like my writing was retrospective childhood memoir in junior college, psychadelic rule breaking chaotic word game dance face trembles through Cal, and now it's become a mixture of psychadelic retrospect and rambley business plans.  END
BEGIN NOW As of late my creative goals have become oriented around triggering the act of creation in others.  END
BEGIN NOW Since the central goal is to prompt the act of expression, the central technique should be very detached from intellectualization and closer to the immediate and measurable experience of reality.  END
BEGIN NOW If this is the central goal and purpose than simply the act ought to suffice, self justify, and such and so on.  END
BEGIN NOW In this vein I've forced myself to become detatched from the concept of a complete and cohesive project, dedicating my efforts to getting lost in the detail. END
BEGIN NOW But sludging through this stream of quagulated phlegm, pushing against a stream of lights launching out of the screen, pushing eyes deeper in, pulling attention further out, further further away from the self aware origins of mind and self.  END

BEGIN NOW 	UNDERLYING MECHANISMS END
BEGIN NOW Autonomous Education  (A.E.)  END
BEGIN NOW Creative Expressions Therapy.  END
BEGIN NOW (C.E.T.) END
BEGIN NOW 	To develop and present these concepts, fictional characters are made to discuss the subject matter, so that each one can fully believe whatever thoughts I'm toying with, leaving me free to continue my cynical predilection.  END
BEGIN NOW The characters provide an actual demonstration of how one might use self guided education techniques (A.E.) to develop their own course of C.E.T.  END

BEGIN NOW 	ONE LAST TIME END
BEGIN NOW 	What follows is a series of psychological proposals developed by the author over the last ten years aimed at helping writers churn up their inner whatnot.  END
BEGIN NOW They occur in the form of character fictions which embody various personality traits and or belief systems the author has contemplated acquiring, studying the effects of traits on types and systems on specifics in the realm of personality, and how it is embodied in the various realms of acquaintancehood.  END
BEGIN NOW Rest assured, the author is much more sane than when he started this project, which is proof that it's a worthy endeavour to chore through the chapters and prompts.  END
BEGIN NOW Join me, dear reader, in the sacred role of scribe, and take the prompts I've gathered to trigger your own streams of expression and awareness.  END
BEGIN NOW And send them to me at slightlydistracted@hotmail.com so that I may bask in the onslaught of absurdity I hope to have triggered. END
BEGIN NOW CHAPTER ONE ---- CALL ON THE MUSE END
BEGIN NOW 	An ancient tradition of epic poetry and such is the call on the muse.  END
BEGIN NOW This is an almost impossible task for the excessively cynical or logical, because the muse is that experience which frees us from such anchors of expression.  END
BEGIN NOW Jack the Bastard struggles to understand this summons, which makes him incapable of truly experiencing it.  END
BEGIN NOW Laughing Peter seems to be permenantly in the company of the muse, which is why he never writes anything down : Because to him it never seems temporary.  END
BEGIN NOW 	Those who wish to follow along and duplicate the prompts are advised to find a pastoral setting, hypnotize yourself, (see appendix : self hypnosis) and when word thoughts become thin and ignorable, seek out that which prompts your very existence and thus might prompt the epic expressions fermenting inside of you. END

BEGIN NOW Thus our hallucenations can be seen more as memory attacks giving us clues as to the root of our subconscious psychological workings.  END

BEGIN NOW Parallel Disciplines END
BEGIN NOW Gardening, Music, and cooking. END
BEGIN NOW Each entails a product, an origin, and an audience.  END
BEGIN NOW Each can be considered a pursuit of perspective in search of self knowledge. END

BEGIN NOW Strategic Partnerships END

BEGIN NOW DUE DILLIGENCE END
BEGIN NOW Every project entails due diligence, but in the business realm this is strictly related to paperwork and money.  END
BEGIN NOW Those who manage to pursue their discipline despite economic irrelevance, and/or a lack of paperwork are those who have made a personal choice to integrate their discipline into their daily lives, not relegating it to a mere day job, wherein they are forced to sacrifice their personal approaches and beliefs.  END

BEGIN NOW Wilson Goes for a Drive END
BEGIN NOW “Matilda!!! Where’s the car wax?” Wilson hollered from the bathroom of the dilapidated double wide. END
BEGIN NOW “It’s on top of the mirror cabinet!” She squealed back.  END
BEGIN NOW “And don’t use it on your horns!! They look disturbing enough without you glorifying them with shimmer!” Matilda continued stirring the thick black beany goop she cooked five nights a week.  END
BEGIN NOW After all, working at a bean factory as head bean counter had its benefits such as infinite bean supply.  END
BEGIN NOW Wilson didn’t mind beans 5 nights a week, but he had become rather irate at her treatment of his horns.  END
BEGIN NOW He considered them a gift from God, as if he were some sort of new age manifestation of Pan, or Abraxas, but she treated them as if they were some sort of curse. END
BEGIN NOW Wilson’s Cutaneous growths had been a topic of much concern to his parents during his youth, and as an adult he had often sported a pompadour so as to minimize their presence, but once he had secured Matilda as his life mate, he had become more lax in letting them poke through, occasionally even slicking his hair back and shining his horns so as to haunt the neighborhood with his bizarre gift. END
BEGIN NOW They weren’t massive, only poking a conservative 3 inches up, curling gently back like a mule deer.  END
BEGIN NOW Nothing quite so fancy as the legendary Jackalope.  END
BEGIN NOW He often walked downtown right through soap box square in Gamlar park, simply to watch the self appointed preachers lose their shit, suddenly stopping mid holler, staring agape.  END
BEGIN NOW Occasionally he’d pass one who would quickly launch into a new torrent of world abuse, using Wilson as the central demonstration of the decline of human morality.  END
BEGIN NOW Wilson would listen with a tight lipped smile and feel his stomach curl into the density and power of a black hole.  END
BEGIN NOW These fools.  END
BEGIN NOW What do they know? Flaunting ancient superstitions to provoke mass hysteria amongst the commoners, too busy doing the hamster dance to consider what sort of belief system their very lives demonstrated. END
BEGIN NOW Wilson held the shammy with a soft grip and dipped it gently into the wax, letting his eyes lay across the bright red surface of his RX7.  END
BEGIN NOW His flying squirrel.  END
BEGIN NOW Same car since he had started dating Matilda who had affectionately named it Rocky, unaware that Rocky was a gray squirrel, only interested in the flying reference.  END
BEGIN NOW Wilson had ceded the point, happy to have a mate who would take part in his life, going so far as to name his conveyance.  END
BEGIN NOW Rocky had been on many a voyage, and Wilson had always been a cautious and caring companion to his car, coming home several times with pictures of it perched on romantic rocky cliffs he had visited while Matilda stayed home painting ceramic figurines.  END
BEGIN NOW Their house had become filled wall to wall with dozens and dozens of tiny shelves, all attached to the wall, all occupied by armies of miniatures.  END
BEGIN NOW The foyer and living room and bathroom and guest bedroom were all inhabited by over a thousand tiny furry animal creatures, all cutesy and bizarre, wearing old English hats and boots, holding shovels and pushing plows. END
BEGIN NOW Wilson didn’t mind the experience of living in some sort of lilliputian museum, in fact he was glad that his wife had something so intricate and cute to keep her busy while he was out pondering the purpose of his horns.  END
BEGIN NOW He didn’t accept anyone else’s maligning of his growths, but he harbored a wonderment as to what purpose they might end up serving.  END
BEGIN NOW The biggest fight they had ever gotten into was when Matilda had brought home a file big enough to grind his gift down to nubbins.  END
BEGIN NOW He was shocked and offended at her suggestion of cutaneous castration, and had been very clear to her as to who or what might leave his life first, her or the horns. END
BEGIN NOW Today, he planned on taking a spin along Ridge road, to the canyon that led up past several springs to Summit, where he would sit and stroke his shiny horns, and holler wildly at anyone who drove past, letting out his inner banshee… He found this a soothing practice to keep his bizarre fixation in check.  END
BEGIN NOW He was here, he felt, to startle the commoners.  END
BEGIN NOW To bring discomfort to those who had let themselves become stagnant and cyclical.  END
BEGIN NOW He felt compelled to live out his bizarre craving for a startling role.  END
BEGIN NOW He got in his car, and slicked his hair back, and worked a little of the wax into his crustacean enigmas, or whatever.  END
BEGIN NOW Than he got into his shiny red RX 7 and sped off towards Ridge Road and beyond. END
BEGIN NOW Wilson was not afraid of divine retribution. END

BEGIN NOW 3.  END
BEGIN NOW Papa Charles Plans a Riot END
BEGIN NOW The boys had been drinking since last whistle, starting in the parking lot with their lunchbox bottles, and Papa Charles had quietly sipped on his pocket flask while they slowly turned the evening into a full on over charged whip rigged rally about how to get their well deserved pay for the two thousand chairs and 300 tables and 500 mantle pieces they had made which had caused the callouses and muscles to appear on their forms which would now soon be turned towards causing a storm to remind all the powers that be what full power there seethed in the bosom of all of their greed.  END
BEGIN NOW The night had been chosen according to astrology, old Gypsy Fingers had been summoned in to decide when the best day within the next month might be for overturning the powers that be. END
BEGIN NOW He had said next Wednesday would function quite nicely, and didn’t bother to tell them it was ‘cause his new dinette set was due to arrive on Monday, and they were usually late, so he gave the delivery crew an extra day to extract his purchase before starting some sort of hedonistic riot to demonstrate worker frustration with not getting paid. END
BEGIN NOW “They have a cafeteria.” Cried Meek Joe in a flurry of drunken gesticulations.  END
BEGIN NOW “We get free food! You wanna just walk away from that as if it doesn’t feed you?!?!” END
BEGIN NOW “We are not dogs to accept simply food.” Replied Papa Charles, now slightly enthused.  END
BEGIN NOW He had finished his flask and than had it refilled by young willy the bartender, a tousled blonde dude whom the workers had watched grow from child of four, son of Big Bart the Log Splitter who lived out near Jude, the town on the far side of Summit hill, up on the mountain where only the lonely and lost tend to go. END
BEGIN NOW “I bring home my leftovers to my wife, and we don’t have a child yet, so we manage to survive on just the cafeteria food.  END
BEGIN NOW I can’t just compromise my wife’s meals because you want to prove we’re not afraid.  END
BEGIN NOW We ARE afraid!! Can’t you see that?!” END
BEGIN NOW “Silence Meek Joe! It is no for you to say.  END
BEGIN NOW We have demonstrated the two sides of the problem, and it’s left to the workers to decide.” Papa Charles raised his hands and spread them like Moses.  END
BEGIN NOW “Who among you is unwilling to risk the meager benefits that we manage to eek out from this brutish Pewterschmidt, and this pompous Bierbach?! Let them leave now, and protect their pitiful wages.” Papa Charles paused and peered aggressively into the audience, dismantling the psychology of each man, pausing long enough to give them a brief flash of approval.  END
BEGIN NOW After an elongated stretching infinite pausingly painful fifteen seconds, Papa Charles spoke once more.  END
BEGIN NOW “And who among you is ready to rally and force our new-found awareness upon those who have fallen into luxurious excess at our expense? And who is ready to risk! To risk and to taunt and to prove and to demonstrate?! Who among you?!?! Who among you?!?!” END
BEGIN NOW The whiskey had finally taken over for Papa Charles. END

BEGIN NOW 4.  END
BEGIN NOW Franky Goes to Jail END
BEGIN NOW Franky hated hot dogs.  END
BEGIN NOW He hated cafeteria eggs.  END
BEGIN NOW Franky hated most of the food they forced on him at the P & B Penal Farm.  END
BEGIN NOW He hated most things about the place.  END
BEGIN NOW He had already burned the place down once, and was known and respected throughout the prison as the saboteur du monde, and this was one of his few joys.  END
BEGIN NOW People gave him their deserts, simply because he was saboteur du monde.  END
BEGIN NOW People gave him cigarettes in the yard.  END
BEGIN NOW Simply because he was who he was.  END
BEGIN NOW Ironically, he was falsely accused and had never burned anything down, but after 10 years of denying it, he had given it up and settled into the various perks of being known as saboteur du monde. END
BEGIN NOW His time was almost up.  END
BEGIN NOW It had been 40 years for aggravated arson, inciting a riot, and punching a cop.  END
BEGIN NOW He had been 19 at the time, and was planning on moving out of California, possibly up the coast to Oregon, to get in some of that early early retirement he had grown up expecting.  END
BEGIN NOW His uncle was in Eugene, the land of misfit joys, where all the sub-genres go to die.  END
BEGIN NOW He had been there once, to attend his uncle’s wedding, but hadn’t been back in years, and was looking forward to leaving.  END
BEGIN NOW The night before he left, he had decided to meet his old slacker buddies at the local bar, Dave’s.  END
BEGIN NOW He knew it was a bad idea, and he was hoping only Jack and Pete would come, and not bring Jack’s cousin Timmy the timid, a quietly psychotic addition to the once calm and joyful crew. END
BEGIN NOW These days it seemed like the group of friends spent most of their time trying to deal with Timmy’s destructive penchant for chaos.  END
BEGIN NOW There was the time he removed all the lug nuts from a police cruiser while the cops were getting donuts, and taunted them into chasing him in their car, only to have all the wheels fall off one at a time, until the cruiser was crouched on the ground like a landlocked boat.  END
BEGIN NOW He had come across 100 gallons of black paint once, and decided that handicapped people ought not get first dibs on the good parking, and took it upon himself to dump the goopy mess and spread it with a push broom in front of the local grocery store.  END
BEGIN NOW “EQUALITY!!” He had hollered, as the cops dragged him off. END
BEGIN NOW He was known in the town, and cops always stopped him when they saw him, sure he was up to no good, for truly that’s all he was ever up to.  END
BEGIN NOW His parents had given him a car for graduation, but when he used it to create a shortcut through the neighbor’s field, they had tried to reclaim the machine, only to wake one morning and find it in flames in their driveway.  END
BEGIN NOW Timmy claimed ignorance, but they had nothing left to take from him, seeing as his room was empty and grey, his friend group only barely tolerated him, and would tell him to find his own time to cause chaotic nonsense. END
BEGIN NOW Franky took his seat at the bar and ordered a beer, and was distraught to see two officers enter behind him.  END
BEGIN NOW Jack and Pete would be here soon, no doubt with Timmy in tow, who would inevitably cause problems and compromise Franky’s graceful exit from the town. END
BEGIN NOW Franky hesitantly sipped his beer and ran a shaky hand through his red hair.  END
BEGIN NOW He was done with this town.  END
BEGIN NOW He was happy and comfortable with the thought, but the time and space between him and his exit had him highly pensive.  END
BEGIN NOW He needed a cigarette.  END
BEGIN NOW He stood and walked towards the door, and was met by Jack Pete and Timmy just coming in the door. END
BEGIN NOW ”Hello, you fellows! I’m off to the tobacco zone.  END
BEGIN NOW I’ll be inside in a second.” END
BEGIN NOW Jack and Timmy continued past, but Pete paused, seeing the cops. END

BEGIN NOW ”ITS GONNA FALL!!! GET BACK!!! GET OUT OF THE WAY!!! IT’S BURNING!!” He felt a bit silly for saying something as obvious as “It’s Burning” but he continued anyways, unabated, jamming his way between bodies, towards a tree that had once been in a small 8x8 garden bed, and now was swarmed, looking like a flailing creature caught in a stampede. BEGIN NOW 6.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles the Bard END
BEGIN NOW A dull hollow roar was making its way down the rocky canyon, along the swarming river.  END
BEGIN NOW Squirrels and rabbit skittered out of the clear beach front.  END
BEGIN NOW A humming cackle of nonsense words accompanied the sound, and it all blended in to a common texture and rhythm. END
BEGIN NOW “Now Charles, I want you to go into a deep trance.” Charles heard in his head.  END
BEGIN NOW It was his soothing narrator who would always chime in when he had achieved the proper blend of industrial sounds and natural sounds.  END
BEGIN NOW The roar of the river and the screech of his dirt bike had brought him to his Samsara or whatever.  END
BEGIN NOW “You’re falling backwards now, charles, falling backwards through infinite darkness, away from nothing, and towards nothing.  END
BEGIN NOW You are free and fluid, nothing to impede or distract you from your perfect pure and pointed plummet from nowhere, into nothing.” Charles’s eyes began to shine.  END
BEGIN NOW The trail along the river warped and burbled over roots and rocks, and his internal rhythm became attached to the pattern of these impediments occurring.  END
BEGIN NOW He began to hum softly. END
BEGIN NOW “Hmmmmmmm” and it slowly grew into a vowel sound, perhaps aaaaaaahhhhh.  END
BEGIN NOW The narrator dropped away softly, and Charles began adding consonant impediments for his path of voweling warbles.  END
BEGIN NOW “aaaaaaaabbaaagaaaaaan  END
BEGIN NOW aaa beeeeeeee  gaaaaaaaa  … END
BEGIN NOW I began in a manner not normal nor needed END
BEGIN NOW in all this eternal befuddling dreaming END
BEGIN NOW and on through the mist I’ve been falling for ages END
BEGIN NOW past wizards and warriors, slack jaws and sages, END
BEGIN NOW its on through the morning and into the noon END
BEGIN NOW hat we call on through falling sun nothing to prove.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s the age old dilemma to dance or to die END
BEGIN NOW and we all go to heaven so never be trying END
BEGIN NOW o last out a moment or two til you’re future END
BEGIN NOW is all that you’ve chosen and nothing to suture, END
BEGIN NOW for its but a game and the moment a penny END
BEGIN NOW and if we were children we’d all become venison.  END
BEGIN NOW Nothing to say no one cries out your name END
BEGIN NOW it’s the same old derangement that strangles our brains, END
BEGIN NOW if we can’t find the sunlight we’re doomed in the twilight END
BEGIN NOW of waking to find that our life is what we want.  END
BEGIN NOW Don’t pause in the doorway nor dim down the lights END
BEGIN NOW as it all comes to nothing, our meaningless flights.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s a dreary old maiden who holds out the fig leaf END
BEGIN NOW and craves we behave in the cold shattered streets END
BEGIN NOW I’ve lost all the most holy of leftover longings END
BEGIN NOW we struggle so long to get back to the stream END
BEGIN NOW by the cleft in the valley we once knew so well END
BEGIN NOW we once once grew up and flew through to heaven from hell END
BEGIN NOW and it’s almost a mystery how did we come to this now?” END
BEGIN NOW All of a sudden the fox was right beneath Dark Charles’s tire.  END
BEGIN NOW A squishy pop, and the massive rodent was no more.  END
BEGIN NOW Dark Charles came screeching to a sudden stop, and hopped off his bike.  END
BEGIN NOW The fox lay there twitching terribly, in the throes of his death rattle.  END
BEGIN NOW Dark Charles approached, and for a moment wore an expression of grave mourning.  END
BEGIN NOW This had been the only creature in all the world he trusted.  END
BEGIN NOW He always knew where the fox would be, when it would approach from the bushes.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles even knew which bush it would be appearing from.  END
BEGIN NOW But this time he had been too deep in his hypnotic rambling trance to know when where or how quickly his fox friend would approach.  END
BEGIN NOW He had failed his sacred role as caretaker off these innocent woods.  END
BEGIN NOW All this ran through his head in less than a second before he stomped his heel down swiftly, breaking the fox’s neck and sending it quickly to the other side.  END
BEGIN NOW There was no tear in Charles’s eye. END
BEGIN NOW He picked the corpse up and slung it into a canvas sack which he tied down to his dirt bike, and immediately hopped back on his bike, and let out a deep and mournful wail, which he slowly modified with consonant sounds until he was rambling actual words which pulled themselves together into a coherent culling song. BEGIN NOW “Aaaaaaaaaaeeeeeeeee……. END
BEGIN NOW Aaaaammmmm  Heeeeeeeeeee…. END
BEGIN NOW I let it go and looked aloft, END
BEGIN NOW I lost a life I trailed off.  END
BEGIN NOW I cannot be what is the cause of all this, END
BEGIN NOW its larger and less we shall all be the guest END
BEGIN NOW in the end of the great lonely reaper to be END
BEGIN NOW in the presence of he pleasant sense of relief, END
BEGIN NOW we shall own what we own and move on down the road END
BEGIN NOW o a space made to hold us so deep in the forest.  END
BEGIN NOW I caaaaaa   ot be brokeeeee ….  END
BEGIN NOW By thiiiiiings, I cannot chaaaaaaange.” END

BEGIN NOW 7.  END
BEGIN NOW Frankie and Papa Charles END
BEGIN NOW The new prison was better than the old prison, but it was a subsidiarity of Beirbach and Pewterschmidt Incorporated, built on the ruins of the burnt down factory.  END
BEGIN NOW Beirbach and Pewterschmidt had planned the whole thing, investing in riot insurance and arson insurance for massively more than the factory was worth, and hiring a certain “Stinky Terrance” to soak the Wicker man in gasoline and sabotage it to fall against the factory wall, sending the whole place up, which of course would be full of freshly stained furniture and buckets of varnish with no lids, and all their misfiled lost and thoroughly over cooked books, by chance might be lost in the glorious display of Protesters Incompetence.  END
BEGIN NOW And the immediate redevelopment of the land into a prison, which pumped out the same furniture, only by workers who were paid 5 cents an hour and couldn’t leave. END
BEGIN NOW It was the perfect factory, which Beirbach and Pewterschmidt had been debating ever since building the factory : How might one maximize the functionality and profit margin? And this whole prison gambit was officially a keeper.  END
BEGIN NOW Institutionalized slavery! And to be on the good side of things for once.  END
BEGIN NOW Beirbach and Pewterschmidt had patted each other on the backs for that one.  END
BEGIN NOW And had a tendency to monitor the two prisoners who had been attached to the riots which had caused the burning down of the factory and the building of the prison which now housed them.  END
BEGIN NOW Franky and Papa Charles.  END
BEGIN NOW  They couldn’t have been more different.  END
BEGIN NOW For Pewterschmidt and Beirbach, they were a reminder of a time past, a gamble which paid off marvelously, for every one but Franky and Papa Charles. END
BEGIN NOW Franky had grown harder as time went on, spending his first ten years explaining to everyone that he had not been part nor party to the riots, and had been running from the cops for some unrelated reason, which was also not his fault.  END
BEGIN NOW And he’s got family in Eugene whose probably still waiting for him. END
BEGIN NOW After about a thousand repetitions over the course of ten years, which is only 3 times a day on average, he finally settled in to his new surroundings, and started to adopt a more functional attitude, of crass indifference and aggression.  END
BEGIN NOW He had been thrown into a world that he had to quickly and violently adapt to, and was still off the opinion that nothing could be further from his fault. END
BEGIN NOW Meanwhile, Papa Charles took his time as a retirement.  END
BEGIN NOW He always had a book that he was excited to talk about, he was always distracted by tiny animals and bugs or flowers and dirt patterns on the other side of the yard while everyone else traded cigarettes played cards and lifted weights.  END
BEGIN NOW He was left alone for the most part, because he was Papa Charles.  END
BEGIN NOW He had built this place.  END
BEGIN NOW He and Franky.  END
BEGIN NOW Everyone treated them like holy old timers.  END
BEGIN NOW After all, it had been 40 years.  END
BEGIN NOW They’d been in longer than most of the inmates had been alive.  END
BEGIN NOW And they were finally approaching release. END

BEGIN NOW 8.  END
BEGIN NOW "Dinner's ready!!" Hollered Aunt Dezzie, her portly form filling the doorway to the family double wide trailer.  END

BEGIN NOW Ned was the only one related to Aunt Dezzie.  END
BEGIN NOW He was her son.  END

BEGIN NOW Dezzie and Ned didn't mind.  END

BEGIN NOW Jeff and Dave had met at the military academy and found out that neither of them missed home, and neither of them thought much of this up tight institutionalized compartment making gentrifying simplificator of an approach to pumping out predictable passive citizen types who wouldn't make waves except to crush the ones who stand out or stand up or stand while others sit or stand by the newspaper stand simply because they have nowhere to be.  END

BEGIN NOW Nightmare.  END
BEGIN NOW Leroy was the only one among the group that had grown up with Dezzie and Ned.  END
BEGIN NOW They had always been in the trailer park on the edge of the woods in Northern California on the Oregon border.  END
BEGIN NOW It had always been the way it was, Dezzie cooking, Ned and Leroy wandering the woods and wondering how to track bigfoot or signal a UFO or find out the truth about the free masons and the astronauts and the rock and roll stars who were obviously all in cahoots, sending each other signals in their songs and their architecture and their video footage. BEGIN NOW First they had been convinced that the moon landings were real.  END
BEGIN NOW Than they had found out they were faked on a sound stage in ...  END
BEGIN NOW where was it? New Mexico? And the proof was the flag flappin, because there aint no wind on the moon.  END
BEGIN NOW But than some old timer they met at the bar had explained to them that there was still rotation on the moon, and the rotation was enough to send the flag flying in one particular direction, and our flags only fell limp when the rotation perfectly canceled out the wind, and really it was all real.  END
BEGIN NOW The old timer had claimed to have been a janitor on the space shuttle, and had wiped down the seats and scrubbed the control panels and shaken hands with leo armstrong or what was it.  END
BEGIN NOW Leroy and Ned had been real excited by this interaction, and had come up with a new theory, the moon landings were pretended to be fake so that the american people would be unaware just how advanced government technology really was, and we were already on mars and pluto, and harvesting natural gasses from Jupiter to run through our stoves and cook our foods.  END
BEGIN NOW After all, weren't we due to run out of natural gasses pretty soon? And this had led them to the alternative fuels discussion, and a dozen different drifters who came through town telling the boys high tales about the new car that runs on water, and how corn will solve all our problems, and how solar is a lie because it takes more energy to build, and there are diamonds that just give off energy all day, and we just have to bring the right kind of diamond into a cave and wait for it to glow or wiggle or something, and the deeper in the ground it is, the more likely it is to occur.  END
BEGIN NOW Ned and Leroy weren't so much into figuring out how it Actually was, they were just more fascinated by the infinite number of ideas that people thought must be happening.  END

BEGIN NOW Whatever the scenes are."  END
BEGIN NOW "I'd say that makes a lot of sense Leroy." Replied Ned as they tried once more to calibrate their Bigfoot call.  END
BEGIN NOW It was a predator call that had been modified with a resonance chamber and an amplifier so that it would hit more frequencies at higher and lower octaves simultaneously than any other call on the market.  END
BEGIN NOW If it worked like they hoped it would, they expected a veritable Noah's ark to show up, which is why they had chosen to climb the tallest tree they could manage before plugging it in, hooking it up, giving each other the lucky hand shake with their fingers intertwined and spitting in opposite directions. BEGIN NOW 11.  END
BEGIN NOW Without the fox, there was nothing holding Charles the Bard in the Big Sur Mess.  END

BEGIN NOW 16.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles had always held onto the wallet full of cash he had when he first arrived in the wilderness as a keepsake of a time past, when he lacked the resilient strength and freedom required to truly survive on his own simple gumption.  END
BEGIN NOW Many a time he had pulled out the lincolnswashingtons and benjamins and contemplated their somber faces with a laughing indifference, all but forgetting the historical relevance for their monetary remembrance.  END
BEGIN NOW It tickled a far corner of his brain, what might have made these few important enough to flash their stony faces in the midst of every financial exchange.  END
BEGIN NOW what a strange rememberance and at long last they had once more become relevant.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles remembered the last time he had passed one of these bills across a counter to be counted and filed away in the register by a pimply faced boy of sixteen in exchange for a foraging guide of the pacific mid coast.  END
BEGIN NOW it had cost one hamilton and several lincolns, and he had received in exchange 300 pages of ewell gibbons, the well known survivor and student of all things wild and edible.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles found it incredible that we was finally ready to return, He could barely remember why he had left.  END
BEGIN NOW It had been a wednesday.  END
BEGIN NOW He knew this because the marquis was being changed as he passed in front of the theater along the empty downtown strip that early morning for his final time.  END
BEGIN NOW Pacific Grove had been kind to him and he felt no resentment for the pavement nor the painted parking lot lines nor the street lights or storefronts or hand painted signs.  END
BEGIN NOW He had left with disdain for no man, only a strong surging mournfulness for the passing of his mother charlotte, truly the most decent person who had ever lived.  END
BEGIN NOW He had helped her many a time in his youth open Barrymore Bakery.  END
BEGIN NOW He'd sweep off the stoop as she made the sweet cakes that they'd sell to the regulars, old man Standish with his bristly pine cone moustache, one sugarless cookie and coffee always black, missus quince, the school marm in her subtle conservative garments garnering two dozen jelly filleds every friday to keep the kids enthused.  END
BEGIN NOW Jack the plumber, steve the sweeper, fred and jerry from the hardware store next door.  END
BEGIN NOW The list went on, but so did charles, on past the welcome to pacific grove sign, on along seventeen mile drive, on down past the golf course and light house and downtown carmel, into primordial landscapes that stretched through human concepts of heaven and hell.  END
BEGIN NOW It had all fallen still.  END
BEGIN NOW It had become a vignette without his mother Charlotte he didn't care what came next.  END
BEGIN NOW He had even showed up to open the shop that morning after her death, but paused before the still locked door he couldn't bear the thought.  END
BEGIN NOW So now he was gone, and now 10 years later he was on his way back.  END
BEGIN NOW He had turned inward to find his mom, and no longer felt the lack.  END
BEGIN NOW Without the fox to hold him near to the natural setting he had sent himself to, he was ready to wander back into the human universe.  END
BEGIN NOW His dirt bike barked him along towards a futures as yet unclear.  END
BEGIN NOW Perhaps back to Barrymore's to see who still held the place dear? Perhaps just find a quiet spot to lay down and die, not disturb the dirty world that seemed to be doing just fine.  END

BEGIN NOW 7. END
BEGIN NOW Charles the Bard stood up on top of the train and screamed up into the storm.  END
BEGIN NOW He screamed many things, about how he would not be broken, about how there was no God but is God, about how there was no future nor past, only this infinite present moment that was created by this electricity and compromised by this train and shuddering perpetual with encasements of life water constantly hurtling through infinitude to crash upon the metal roof of these carriages carrying strangers and supplies from one end of the continent to the other, corn for wood, liquor for eggs, tobacco for oranges, paper for pens, led for bullets, milk for bacon, fish for condoms, cow parts for pig parts, blue chips for gold stars, pink ribbons for black and white movies, red flags for yellow lizards.  END
BEGIN NOW The noise Charles was making was his usual blend of ignominious chaos, and this new level of train sounds compromised by and compromising God’s grand orchestra, the thunder storm, Charles in between cast his cackling orchestrations into the infinitely small space between these levels, and he felt as if his voice was within every shudder shake and shift of the the train body gut farm and the swirling psychotic storm essence that embraced and inflamed all Charles’s senses, he felt as alive as the moment he was born, he felt as free as the moment he was born, he felt as pure and infinite as the moment just before.  END
BEGIN NOW He sang and he cried and his tears mingled with rain drops and chased each other down his face like liquid bobsledders on a very hairy course, cruising along crusty chin funk that poor Charles had been far too out there for far too long to ever understand about cleaning up and trimming down and leaving off and upending the damp ends of his outward appearance, but instead he had found his all holy ritual of sacrificing his entire capacity his entire essence, stepping out up and in to the world of the storm and praying for release, new birth, or baptism, whichever God might consider the intentional act of pursuing lighting contact.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles was convinced it would bring him all the information that humans needed to finally perfect their lives and live in a world without violence or greed, pain anger or confusion.  END
BEGIN NOW He knew of course that there would be forms of all this, but it would be purified and it would never be at the cost of another creatures well being.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles was very sure all this would work out because he had lived in nature long enough to know.  END
BEGIN NOW Nature always wins, and it always does fascinating things, especially behind the scenes, with byproducts that we don’t seem to know about or how to manifest into the proper channel of accessibility to other byproducts to turn all aspects into part of the overall cycle and exchange.  END
BEGIN NOW But Charles didn’t know how to explain this or say it, and dare I say it still remains unexplained and unportrayed to say the least.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles had come up with his utopian vision in big sur, and had never really completely understood it himself, because the utopioan vignettes he seemed most aware of were the ones that most large creatures left undisturbed.  END
BEGIN NOW He had a fondness for the unusable.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles envisioned a world where no one did anything ever, except for wander and sing and forage and start small fires with very few materials.  END
BEGIN NOW His was not the closed off broken built up cordoned quarantined and drawn and quartered city of crumbles and kings.  END
BEGIN NOW His was the neglected pathway, the overgrown meadow, and the shimmering dew of some other morning that the universe would never understand nor see through the eyes that Charles saw.  END
BEGIN NOW And this thunderstorm atop a train going from San Francisco to Sacramento, screaming along through the water sky plains of outer nowhere, Charles felt as though he had busted through into infinity again. END
