BEGIN NOW 12.  END
BEGIN NOW The voyage on the train ended up being far less eventful than Charles the Bard had expected.  END
BEGIN NOW He recalled the immense release of his being astride the land leviathan, he even remembered seeing the river coming up and feeling unchangeably compelled to make the leap, timing it so that he didn't crush himself against the walls of the canyon, being oh so cautious to launch out far enough to not bounce against the sides of the train or the tressel that held it aloft the massive gorge of a river.  END
BEGIN NOW He hadn't made it to Sacramento, but the name meant nothing to him beyond the vague memory of what a sacrament was.  END
BEGIN NOW something holy.  END
BEGIN NOW something worth working towards.  END
BEGIN NOW he had seen the river beneath him during the storm and felt it his official sacrificial sacramental duty to launch and fall and flail freely.  END
BEGIN NOW sweeet sweeet free fall.  END
BEGIN NOW no one else would ever understand it.  END
BEGIN NOW He had already gotten used to the flaccid passive floppy baggy forms that domesticated humans seemed to exhibit.  END
BEGIN NOW They were not surviving, but being softened by society.  END
BEGIN NOW he was unsure if he really did come from the same species as these creatures.  END
BEGIN NOW He was not offended or bothered by them, he simply didn't feel the connection that he expected.  END
BEGIN NOW He'd seen the ants swarming over each other, almost becoming one cohesive creature, one singular being He did not feel similar flock or tribe or fleet sentiment concerning these busy strange bumping awkward humanoid habit formed installations of Universe At large.  END
BEGIN NOW The small town felt more aligned with something he could understand.  END
BEGIN NOW They moved along slowly like deer in the forest.  END
BEGIN NOW They exchanged greetings and awarenesses with the concern a chipmunk gives a grass hopper or a moth gives a frog.  END
BEGIN NOW They were aware of each other, but were not reliant on the other to acknowledge or offer or sacrifice anything at their behest.  END
BEGIN NOW Charles the Bard almost felt human among these rural types.  END
BEGIN NOW it left him befuddled as to how to integrate himself with them.  END
BEGIN NOW He simply kept passing from town to town, walking mostly, 20 or 30 or 40 miles a day, pausing to camp wherever he was whenever he felt like it.  END
BEGIN NOW In this way he made his way from Grass Valley through a dozen tiny towns such as angels camp and mariposa further and further directionless, always south, simply because it felt more inviting.  END
BEGIN NOW Little did he know he was following clues back to his Etruscan plate, the mess canyon of Big Sur.  END
BEGIN NOW He had been wandering through his curious pattern for a week now, and was looking west from san juan batista, wondering why he had ended up in this strange intermediary zone .  END

BEGIN NOW CHAPTER ONE :: DOLORES, JACK & PAPS END
BEGIN NOW Dolores never quite understood what the specifics of each ceremony meant, and while intrigued, she couldn't seem to see the meaning in all these peoples wailing and gnashing of teeth and their odd ways of cherishing ancestral essence which generally tended to end up blocking out any positivity, lost in the wailing, lost in the gloaming, lost in the lonely hollow hateful feelings of these strangers standing so lonely in the rain by the grave stones. END
BEGIN NOW Dolores never asked any questions for truth, rather accepting the fact that any individual's answer was simply that : THEIR answer.  END
BEGIN NOW When she was seven and eight and nine her uncle and father had continually filled her with unrelated theories and folklores about the origins of pot holes and why water flows down hill, and where all the buffalo went.  END
BEGIN NOW She eventually decided that since her paternal relatives thought in such diverse unrelated patterns and saw such diverse stories in such similar triggers while being from such a similar origin, all truth must only be applicable the moment it happened, and afterwards was malleable mush in the hands of the experts who could look at ten thousand clues and prove beyond a doubt a dozen different ways how all this came about, and yet, Dolores knew that while it was all true, it was also all nonsense and projection.  END
BEGIN NOW This is why she enjoyed here alcove of manzanita gnarl on the hillside above the graveyard where she was shielded from the eyes of prying strangers by the gnarled exploding branch arms that tangle the thicket of her hidden visitor viewing perch for watching strangers in ritual. END
BEGIN NOW Dolores had been born at the mortuary, and was often surprised to hear that their sliver of rural perfection was rarely if ever found elsewhere.  END
BEGIN NOW Mortuaries weren't like this anywhere, or at least that's what her uncle Jack had been saying the previous night over sangria and backwood cigars. END

BEGIN NOW CHAPTER THREE :: LAUGHING PETER END
BEGIN NOW Jack crawled up the final sandstone stretch to the ridge, and was welcomed with a blast of warm air and a shimmering star speckled sky of silky blackness and a side of lunar sliver astride the horizon.  END
BEGIN NOW He wiped his shaggy Sam Elliot moustache and scratched his raggedy mane.  END
BEGIN NOW The valley felt quiet tonight.  END
BEGIN NOW Quiet but angry.  END
BEGIN NOW Burning with the primal torment of survival, free from the sharp pains of social complication.  END

BEGIN NOW Must be the Larkin orchard.  END
BEGIN NOW Jack paused long enough to soak in the scene, but quickly continued on a new detour : up and along the ridge instead of over the ridge and down into town.  END
BEGIN NOW Jack knew he had never been there, but it seemed so similar to the old haunts he and Paps had pursued and cherished as children.  END
BEGIN NOW There had been walls of carvings covered in sandstone faces they had hesitated to add to, wondering in their child minds whether it might be original American Indian artwork, and perhaps it was But that was a different valley a hundred miles from here.  END
BEGIN NOW After an hour of hiking along the ridge, negotiating the occasional unpassable shrubby snare by climbing a tree or belly crawling, and finally, Jack came upon something he would end up spending years trying to forget, though finally, it gave him a chance to remember himself and his own history in a better way.  END
BEGIN NOW Though it was still pretty messed up. END
BEGIN NOW carved in the wall he found scratchings and markings.  END
BEGIN NOW Illegible but obviously there at some point.  END
BEGIN NOW It looked like a whole paragraph carved into the sand stone.  END
BEGIN NOW He couldn't make it out, especially not in the moonlight, but in the bottom right corner where a signature would be was a blast hole in the sandstone, some stained spatter, and a crumpled pile of human bones, bleached and dried as if they had always been there.  END
BEGIN NOW Jack reeled at the sight of the bones, and decided to get out of there before whatever killed that man got ahold of him.  END
BEGIN NOW He turned and quickly wobbled back the way he came, stumbling a bit harder due to his newfound worry that a boogey man or cannibal native might be waiting around the next rock face, but as he turned the corner he had a thought and scampered back to the scene for one last thing. END

BEGIN NOW CHAPTER SIX ::: HURRICANE END
BEGIN NOW "What do you do when you stop liking yourself?" Dolores asked the old man with the beard the wrinkles and the bottle. END

BEGIN NOW Old Hurricane Face had stolen her attention with his gnarled archaic woodgrain face and philosophy.  END

BEGIN NOW CHAPTER NINE ::  NARRATORIAL BREAKDOWN END
BEGIN NOW I wasn't really looking for Dolores.  END
BEGIN NOW She was old enough to disappear for her own reasons, and I was relaxed enough, for the first time in my life, to just be where I was, and let that continually be what it is.  END

BEGIN NOW 'cause that's called fiction.  END

BEGIN NOW And how powerful and profound it was. END
BEGIN NOW The death of the narrator is a joyous occasion.  END
BEGIN NOW The birth of the action is also a pretty neat thing, but that seems to be beyond me at this point.  END
BEGIN NOW One crux seems to be my problem with telling the truth, or at least wanting to.  END
BEGIN NOW This makes all stories false in that their emphasis is overly specific, and the story ends when the focus is resolved.  END
BEGIN NOW This is not reality, this is not truth.  END
BEGIN NOW This only serves to teach people to shrink further into their own heads, expecting something out there to fix what ever seems to be misfiring in here. END
BEGIN NOW All these fictional characters have arrived at a new point, become new people even.  END

BEGIN NOW This leaves me, the author, in a bind.  END
BEGIN NOW If I were to prompt some unprecedented change in the lucks of these characters, I'd be forcing it.  END
BEGIN NOW These characters occurred in my subconscious because they each carry a conundrum that I've been toying with as of late. END

BEGIN NOW There’s something to be said about dining alone.  END
BEGIN NOW The art and science of it.  END
BEGIN NOW Especially in a big city with the world at your feet and options everywhere.  END
BEGIN NOW Selection is the first crucial step.  END
BEGIN NOW If you happen to own a car like the bourgeoisie asshole that you are, abandon the heap as soon as possible, maybe with a free to a good home sign on the windshield and the keys sitting on the front seat.  END
BEGIN NOW Now that you’re a little alleviated, pick a street and start walking.  END
BEGIN NOW Walk until you come to an intersection with as many options as possible.  END
BEGIN NOW Pick a direction that looks laden with restaurants.  END
BEGIN NOW When the mattress stores and furniture outlets pan out and the mechanics have faded into the background of the urban mishmash the glow of neon signs will bloom over the gateways to fine cuisine.  END
BEGIN NOW If you have any preference about ethnicity or cultural settings for your dining experience, now is the time to keep that in mind.  END
BEGIN NOW You will be distracted by convenience, proximity and attractive front window displays.  END
BEGIN NOW Don’t be deceived.  END
BEGIN NOW Keep the original intent in mind.  END
BEGIN NOW This is important for dining alone properly. END
BEGIN NOW My problem was of a calendar nature.  END
BEGIN NOW It was a Sunday after Christmas.  END
BEGIN NOW I had been walking for the better part of an hour with hunger welling up to my neck and the coffee and cigarettes throughout the day beginning to take their toll on me.  END
BEGIN NOW I had had it in my head since waking that I wanted to eat some Chinese for the first time in months.  END
BEGIN NOW Chinese food sounded so exotic and in contrast to my usual diet of work scraps and dollar store noodles with canned tomato sauce or three days boiling chicken soup.  END
BEGIN NOW The appeal was over whelming.  END
BEGIN NOW I was forced into action. END
BEGIN NOW Around the job there was talk of a fantastic Chinese place up in Albany called China Village.  END
BEGIN NOW But Albany is at least a Bart ride away.  END
BEGIN NOW I had around sixty cent left on my last rail card and figured that now was not the time for a little northbound trek only for the sake of a meal.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s a bit much for the budget.  END

BEGIN NOW She looked at me yesterday and said, END

BEGIN NOW You’re so fucking depressing.” END

BEGIN NOW A note about Chinese restaurants.  END
BEGIN NOW I’ve always had an aversion to the places that set table without chopsticks.  END
BEGIN NOW There’s an inherent barbarous quality to western silverware, the need to cut and stab at the food before eating.  END
BEGIN NOW  I’m pretty sure that Confucius had something to say about that.  END
BEGIN NOW It might have something to do with the reason behind using chopsticks either as a genesis or an afterthought.  END
BEGIN NOW I can’t remember these things.  END
BEGIN NOW Too many details.  END
BEGIN NOW But, the point is, the places that don’t set table with chopsticks are either pandering to the fumble fingers of the western hand or they seem to doubt their own authenticity, or perhaps it’s a gesture of condescending nature.  END
BEGIN NOW  As if anyone that walks in would be able to wield the chopsticks.  END
BEGIN NOW And either way, something about that disturbs me. END
BEGIN NOW This was not a restaurant with chopsticks at the table.  END
BEGIN NOW Just a napkin and a fork.  END
BEGIN NOW Just a place mat concealing the placemat underneath the glass on the table top with a print of the Chinese zodiac on it.  END

BEGIN NOW The rest of the description is lost on me.  END

BEGIN NOW At least with the western zodiac I’m a goat.  END
BEGIN NOW Either way, according to the stars, I belong with the trash.  END
BEGIN NOW But I guess we have a saying about trash and treasure so all is not lost.  END

BEGIN NOW Chapter seven; END
BEGIN NOW There’s something about the houses of geriatrics.  END
BEGIN NOW The smell is something that always lingers.  END
BEGIN NOW It will always smell old in the home of an old person.  END
BEGIN NOW It will be a dull smell.  END
BEGIN NOW Not quite like rot, but close to it.  END
BEGIN NOW Not quite like stagnation, or the smell of dead dreams hidden in the closet.  END
BEGIN NOW It will be a smell of decay, gradual and slightly off putting.  END
BEGIN NOW  Something a long time coming towards death, but not there yet.  END
BEGIN NOW Some people erroneously contribute this to mothballs.  END
BEGIN NOW But they are wrong.  END
BEGIN NOW It is the smell of someone fading away.  END
BEGIN NOW The sense of smell triggers memory better than any other sense a human has.  END
BEGIN NOW The sense of smell is also dulled by familiarity easier than the other senses.  END
BEGIN NOW  Juniper notices nothing unusual about the smell of her home.  END
BEGIN NOW She has walked the halls and lingered in the kitchen long enough never to notice anything about it ever again.  END
BEGIN NOW Juniper Marie Gladstone was born in nineteen twenty three.  END
BEGIN NOW She was born the year of Mailer, the year of Kissinger.  END
BEGIN NOW She has seen the great depression.  END
BEGIN NOW The whole of the Second World War.  END
BEGIN NOW The Vietnam War.  END
BEGIN NOW The Korean War, the Bay of Pigs, the Cuban Missile Crisis.  END
BEGIN NOW She’s no stranger to conflicts coming from the TV screen.  END

BEGIN NOW In the musty dining room of her ranch house, somewhere in the middle of suburbia, Midwest, Juniper sips her tea and looks out the window.  END

BEGIN NOW In her younger days, before the back pain, before Robert passed away and left her the house and the old Volkswagen that since remained parked in the driveway.  END

BEGIN NOW Chapter twelve: END

BEGIN NOW Chapter One: Two Eggs, Over Seas. END
BEGIN NOW Flights out of Romania are few and far between.  END

BEGIN NOW The meal cart is kreeling down the aisle.  END

BEGIN NOW It was made without care and with minimal human contact.  END
BEGIN NOW The potatoes are tasteless .  END

BEGIN NOW The peas received similar treatment.  END

BEGIN NOW There’s a pile of paper that needs to go into the envelopes in front of me.  END
BEGIN NOW And a pot of coffee that I drink out of.  END
BEGIN NOW I fold in silence.  END
BEGIN NOW Delicately placing each piece of paper in each envelope and sealing it with a piece of moist sponge I keep on hand for just such purposes.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m thinking about tomorrow at two.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m thinking about nothing at all. END
BEGIN NOW Curling and Me. END
BEGIN NOW Something strange happened to me in February from the 16th to the 26th of two thousand and ten.  END
BEGIN NOW It started right when the Olympics did.  END
BEGIN NOW It started, really four years ago when I happened upon the game of curling.  END
BEGIN NOW Specifically, women’s curling.  END
BEGIN NOW Color me captivated.  END
BEGIN NOW Somewhere in between shuffleboard and chess on ice.  END
BEGIN NOW I watched it for hours.  END
BEGIN NOW I’d watch women from around the world throw forty-four pound granite rocks at concentric circles on the other end of a hundred and fifty foot long sheet of ice.  END
BEGIN NOW There was something very zen about the whole thing.  END
BEGIN NOW The click of the rocks, the skip screaming her heart out at the sweepers.  END
BEGIN NOW The roar of the crowd after a good draw, a nice chip and roll.  END
BEGIN NOW When the stone sneaks in the hole, into the house and lands right on the button.  END
BEGIN NOW And the crowd goes crazy.  END
BEGIN NOW For two weeks in February I was obsessed.  END
BEGIN NOW I’d check the scores on every game day.  END
BEGIN NOW I’d watch every chance I could, in bars, at home on the computer.  END
BEGIN NOW Each game came curling into my home in the wee hours of night as I’d lie in bed, my legs sore and immobile from working for twelve hours a day.  END
BEGIN NOW  Curling was rest.  END
BEGIN NOW Curling was meditation.  END
BEGIN NOW Curling was a grand game with a lot of pretty faces. END
BEGIN NOW I was helping a restaurant open at the time.  END
BEGIN NOW About two months into the whole thing.  END
BEGIN NOW I was something like third in command of a kitchen that was as serious as it was ridiculous.  END
BEGIN NOW Absurd as it was beautiful .  END
BEGIN NOW As awkward and quirky and disgusting and elegant as a kitchen can be.  END
BEGIN NOW The whole thing hurt my brain and my spirit.  END
BEGIN NOW It was crippling me quickly and I could feel my soul and body being beaten with celery stalks, pelted with onions, crippled with carrots.  END
BEGIN NOW In short, I was tired.  END
BEGIN NOW I was tired all the time.  END
BEGIN NOW I could think and move only on autopilot.  END
BEGIN NOW I was trying my hardest.  END
BEGIN NOW I was working unpaid four hours a day.  END
BEGIN NOW I gave everything my best and my best never seemed good enough.  END
BEGIN NOW Almost daily the chef would take me outside to talk.  END
BEGIN NOW These were usually two to five minute conversations in which I got in maybe two words edgewise and would have been better off just nodding and agreeing.  END
BEGIN NOW My vocabulary was trimmed down to “yes” and “I understand”. END
BEGIN NOW I got off work that day around twelve thirty in the morning.  END
BEGIN NOW There was about an hour left of good drinking time.  END
BEGIN NOW I went straight to the bar on a Wednesday night and sat alone with three to four stools free on either side of me.  END
BEGIN NOW The bartenders were all girls.  END
BEGIN NOW I liked this bar.  END
BEGIN NOW It was a nice place to drink bourbon on a Wednesday night.  END
BEGIN NOW On the TV in the corner, the curling continued.  END
BEGIN NOW The match was Great Britain versus the United States.  END
BEGIN NOW This was the game that changed me.  END
BEGIN NOW This was the moment where I lost touch with reality, sanity and common sense.  END
BEGIN NOW The skip for Great Britain was nineteen years old.  END
BEGIN NOW Youngest skip ever at the Olympics.  END
BEGIN NOW She was fit.  END
BEGIN NOW She was pretty.  END
BEGIN NOW She had won the juniors for the last three years in a row.  END
BEGIN NOW Her name is Eve Muirhead.  END
BEGIN NOW If anything, she was the final stone in my house.  END
BEGIN NOW The hammer that nailed me.  END
BEGIN NOW She could skip my rocks any day.  END
BEGIN NOW If anything it was her contagious passion for the game that took my about the neck, dragged me over the hog line and swept me off my feet.  END
BEGIN NOW The girl could scream.  END
BEGIN NOW The way she yelled at the stone, at the sweepers.  END
BEGIN NOW Just screaming her heart out.  END
BEGIN NOW Always going, “HARD! REALLY HARD!” It was all a bit overwhelming.  END
BEGIN NOW The whiskey and the bar and the curling and the barmaids that spoke about starting their own little curling team.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t believe they were serious.  END
BEGIN NOW They said it seemed like a good game to play while drinking. END
BEGIN NOW “If anything comes back off the grill tonight, I’m moving to Vancouver before tomorrow.  END
BEGIN NOW I won’t be coming to work anymore.  END
BEGIN NOW I think I’ll get a job driving the Zamboni around after hours.  END
BEGIN NOW Practice some curling between the hours of two and four in the morning.  END
BEGIN NOW That sounds nice.” I was sweating proufously and grilling a few hamburgers.  END
BEGIN NOW The sous chef was looking at me with a raised eyebrow.  END
BEGIN NOW She stood short with her hair in a tight bun on the back of her head.  END
BEGIN NOW She always looked at me like she wanted me to shut up.  END
BEGIN NOW I always looked at her as if I knew nothing.  END
BEGIN NOW We had a healthy relationship. END
BEGIN NOW The day was February 23rd.  END
BEGIN NOW It was to be a great day for curling.  END
BEGIN NOW It was rather a day of heartbreak.  END
BEGIN NOW A rather good day for a heartbreak.  END
BEGIN NOW I checked my phone every half hour.  END
BEGIN NOW Checking scores.  END
BEGIN NOW Seeing how the girls were doing.  END
BEGIN NOW I was secretly rooting for the UK.  END
BEGIN NOW I know it was treasonous.  END
BEGIN NOW I know it was wrong.  END
BEGIN NOW But I couldn’t help it.  END
BEGIN NOW I have a soft spot for prodigies.  END
BEGIN NOW  For a hard working nineteen year old commanding a team of women twice her age.  END
BEGIN NOW I heard she plays bagpipes too.  END
BEGIN NOW A real up and comer.  END
BEGIN NOW  A kid defending Scotland, the very country and invented the game, going head to head with Canada, the country that took curling very seriously.  END
BEGIN NOW Heartbreak came in the form of Cheryl Bernard, the Canadian skip.  END
BEGIN NOW She had the look of an old school mate’s mom.  END
BEGIN NOW Like when you go over to a friend’s house after class and you meet his or her mother and they just happened to have a plate of still warm cookies.  END
BEGIN NOW Maybe she was the kind of mom that had milk in a pitcher in the fridge.  END
BEGIN NOW Except that she was Canadian, and they keep their milk in bags. END
BEGIN NOW Concurrently, there was a game between the United States and China.  END
BEGIN NOW This was China’s first time curling at the Olympics.  END
BEGIN NOW They had been training on Canadian soil, over in Alberta.  END
BEGIN NOW Their training must have been extensive.  END
BEGIN NOW They attacked with a kind of technical precision that was borderline evil.  END
BEGIN NOW Calculated and calm, cool and collected.  END
BEGIN NOW I checked the scores.  END
BEGIN NOW Both games tied at 5.  END
BEGIN NOW The tension was slow murder.  END
BEGIN NOW Like being crushed by stone after stone, lowered slowly on your chest until the weight made breathing unbearable.  END
BEGIN NOW I should have been there.  END
BEGIN NOW I should have been in Vancouver shouting my support from the stands.  END
BEGIN NOW Both games went an extra end.  END
BEGIN NOW Both games the teams I rooted for took a beating in the last end.  END
BEGIN NOW And like that, they were out of the running. END
BEGIN NOW “I need more out of you,” he said.  END
BEGIN NOW “I know you’re trying fucking hard and you’re doing a good fucking job.  END
BEGIN NOW But I need more.  END
BEGIN NOW You need to step up in a big way.  END
BEGIN NOW Real fucking type A personality.  END
BEGIN NOW Get in people’s faces when you see something wrong.  END
BEGIN NOW You need to be a fucking man.  END
BEGIN NOW No more of this pussy shit.” END
BEGIN NOW “Yes,” I said.  END
BEGIN NOW “I understand.” I said. END
BEGIN NOW The chef was mad at me again.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t know if it was madness or anger or frustration or what.  END
BEGIN NOW It was like I couldn’t do anything right enough.  END
BEGIN NOW Like there was always something not as good as it could be.  END
BEGIN NOW Like no matter what I did, he didn’t like it.  END
BEGIN NOW He was impossible.  END
BEGIN NOW I was impossible.  END
BEGIN NOW The job was impossible.  END
BEGIN NOW And it had to be done.  END
BEGIN NOW I had to do it.  END
BEGIN NOW All I could do was keep going.  END
BEGIN NOW Forward momentum.  END
BEGIN NOW I needed a sweeper to slick the ice, to keep me going.  END
BEGIN NOW Inch me right into the house.  END
BEGIN NOW I needed to get on the goddamn button.  END
BEGIN NOW But there was always something.  END
BEGIN NOW I took a lot of heat.  END
BEGIN NOW I took a lot of abuse.  END
BEGIN NOW And in my head and my thoughts all I could think about was the semi finals coming up.  END
BEGIN NOW Canada vs.  END
BEGIN NOW Switzerland, China at Sweden.  END
BEGIN NOW Sweden? I hadn’t even noticed Sweden.  END
BEGIN NOW I didn’t know what the world was up against.  END
BEGIN NOW I didn’t count on Anette Norberg.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t think anyone did.  END
BEGIN NOW Except maybe Cheryl Bernard. END
BEGIN NOW After hearing about Sweden’s victory over China, my mind went for another loop.  END
BEGIN NOW I figured China was going to steal this one for sure.  END
BEGIN NOW It seemed like it was going to be China on Canada for the gold.  END
BEGIN NOW Switzerland played well enough, but not consistently enough to be seriously considered.  END
BEGIN NOW Even so.  END
BEGIN NOW These were going to be nail-biters.  END
BEGIN NOW Just about as brutal as curling can be.  END
BEGIN NOW And there I was, stuck at work.  END
BEGIN NOW Cut off from everything that mattered.  END
BEGIN NOW Everything that mattered happened in the semis.  END
BEGIN NOW  The semi final games showed the world how cold blooded Norberg was.  END
BEGIN NOW How ruthless and relentless.  END
BEGIN NOW All the effort in China couldn’t stop her.  END
BEGIN NOW Bernard walked all over Switzerland in her fancy curling shoes.  END
BEGIN NOW She did a little tap dance at the end.  END
BEGIN NOW A little victory dance.  END
BEGIN NOW  A little premature.  END
BEGIN NOW I was at something stupid like seventy-five hours that week.  END
BEGIN NOW I was looking forward to tomorrow.  END
BEGIN NOW The gold medal game.  END
BEGIN NOW Canada vs.  END
BEGIN NOW Sweden.  END
BEGIN NOW I had the day off.  END
BEGIN NOW I was going to wake up at nine to watch China pummel Switzerland back into neutrality.  END
BEGIN NOW Take a nap and catch the three p.m.  END
BEGIN NOW gold game.  END
BEGIN NOW Then there was a disaster.  END
BEGIN NOW The sous chef called in sick.  END
BEGIN NOW An insult.  END
BEGIN NOW A disappointment.  END
BEGIN NOW You don’t call in sick.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t call in sick.  END
BEGIN NOW Not on gold medal day.  END
BEGIN NOW There I was, the only one that could fill her spot.  END
BEGIN NOW  I had to take the hit.  END
BEGIN NOW Go an extra end.  END
BEGIN NOW What’s another eight hours, anyway.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m sure I could catch the game later.  END
BEGIN NOW I went to the restroom and checked the scores.  END
BEGIN NOW Canada 2, Sweden 4.  END
BEGIN NOW Canada 6, Sweden 4.  END
BEGIN NOW Sweden 6, Canada 6.  END
BEGIN NOW Extra end.  END
BEGIN NOW Going into the 11th end.  END
BEGIN NOW I was on my god only knows cup of coffee.  END
BEGIN NOW My hands were shaking, my palms were sweating.  END
BEGIN NOW I had a handful of tickets and a table full of plates. END
BEGIN NOW “You! Go to 203 with the chicken and the kale, positions one and two.” I handed off two plates and three more hit the table.  END
BEGIN NOW I was expediting two hundred and thirty people’s worth of food in a five hour stretch.  END
BEGIN NOW My eyes had enough bags under them to pack for two weeks in Vancouver.  END
BEGIN NOW “Runner! I need a runner!” The ticket machine kept printing.  END
BEGIN NOW I looked at it the same way Eve Muirhead looked at Cheryl Bernard in the tenth.  END
BEGIN NOW Like, why are you doing this to me? Like, why now? Why like this? I’m sure there’s a better way.  END
BEGIN NOW I got off work much later.  END
BEGIN NOW Something around midnight.  END
BEGIN NOW Something like too little too late.  END
BEGIN NOW I checked the scores again.  END
BEGIN NOW Swedish victory, 7-6.  END
BEGIN NOW Sure I wished defeat on Canada for crushing the Brits.  END
BEGIN NOW But still I felt nothing but sour about it.  END
BEGIN NOW Curling is a game of defeat.  END
BEGIN NOW The sweet taste of agony.  END
BEGIN NOW The struggle of futility.  END
BEGIN NOW Curling was something like a great metaphor for life in February.  END
BEGIN NOW  For all my efforts in vain, for all the efforts of the curling teams.  END
BEGIN NOW For all the underdogs that took a bullet.  END
BEGIN NOW To them I raised my bourbon glass and saluted the screen.  END
BEGIN NOW I watched the gold medal game over and over.  END
BEGIN NOW The tenth end is like watching a slow motion punch in the face.  END
BEGIN NOW The hammer in the eleventh is the stone that breaks hearts.  END
BEGIN NOW None of it really mattered anymore.  END
BEGIN NOW It had become a necessary part of me.  END
BEGIN NOW A cancerous, out of control mutation in my brain that helped me disregard everything else in life.  END
BEGIN NOW My affection for that game was like that of an ex-lover.  END
BEGIN NOW You think of them sometimes and feel something you’d rather not try to describe.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t know where I’m going with this anymore.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t understand what to do with my life.  END
BEGIN NOW The Junior Championships started today.  END
BEGIN NOW The women’s championships starts on the 20th.  END
BEGIN NOW All I know is that it’s just beginning.  END
BEGIN NOW And the worst is far from over.  END

BEGIN NOW Part 2: The Chinchilla. END
BEGIN NOW Her name was Nikki.  END
BEGIN NOW We worked together for a good two weeks before she introduced herself.  END
BEGIN NOW She said, “Hi, I’m Nikki.” and I said, “Hi, I’m Nick.”  END
BEGIN NOW “That should be easy to remember,” she said.  END
BEGIN NOW And that’s how we met.  END
BEGIN NOW I remember her blue eyes and her smile.  END
BEGIN NOW The tone and timber of her voice.  END
BEGIN NOW Offensively pleasent.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s what i told her later.  END
BEGIN NOW She had the kind of voice you’d expect on a late night love song radio station.  END
BEGIN NOW She had the kind of voice that could give you the worst news and you’d be ok with it.  END
BEGIN NOW Her voice could sign peace treaties.  END
BEGIN NOW I relized slightly later on that there was something else about her.  END
BEGIN NOW Something that made me believe for a time that she was someone i’d been looking for.  END
BEGIN NOW There’s a line in Hemmingway.  END
BEGIN NOW In The Sun Also Rises.  END
BEGIN NOW When he described Lady Brett for the first time.  END
BEGIN NOW “Her hair was cut short like a boys.  END
BEGIN NOW She started all that.  END
BEGIN NOW And built with curves like the hull of a racing yacht.”  That was Nikki all over.  END
BEGIN NOW And her face was the kind that turned heads and broke them.  END
BEGIN NOW When she didn’t think anyone was looking, her face seemed troubled.  END
BEGIN NOW Things like that.  END
BEGIN NOW little details.  END
BEGIN NOW I’ve always prided myself on my powers of observation.  END
BEGIN NOW And Nikki stole my observations for a good while.  END
BEGIN NOW After our initial meeting not a lot happened for a few days.  END
BEGIN NOW She locked eyes often.  END
BEGIN NOW And little smiles.  END
BEGIN NOW Blushing.  END
BEGIN NOW That kind of thing.  END
BEGIN NOW Then came Murphy’s birthday.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t usually drink with coworkers unless they find me at the bar or it’s a special occassion.  END
BEGIN NOW Someone’s last day.  END
BEGIN NOW Someone’s birthday.  END
BEGIN NOW For Murphy, I’d go out.  END
BEGIN NOW I felt like drinking anyway.  END
BEGIN NOW People went around after work, rallied the troops.  END
BEGIN NOW Nikki seemed hesitant.  END
BEGIN NOW She asked if i was going.  END
BEGIN NOW I said yes.  END
BEGIN NOW She said she would go too.  END
BEGIN NOW I was last out.  END
BEGIN NOW Got out around one.  END
BEGIN NOW Went to the bar, bought Murphy a drink.  END
BEGIN NOW Bought myself three.  END
BEGIN NOW Talked to all the people, smoked many cigarettes.  END
BEGIN NOW Didn’t talk to Nikki.  END
BEGIN NOW One of the other cooks was.  END
BEGIN NOW Then the bar closed.  END
BEGIN NOW  Kat and Dan were offering their place for the after party.  END
BEGIN NOW I knew that ment coke.  END
BEGIN NOW I wasn’t working the next day so I said sure.  END
BEGIN NOW Let’s do this.  END
BEGIN NOW it had been a while anyway.  END
BEGIN NOW I could use an early morning kinda night.  END
BEGIN NOW Then Nikki came along.  END
BEGIN NOW We each did a bump and sat on the couch, petting the dogs and talking until six.  END
BEGIN NOW I didn’t think too much of it.  END
BEGIN NOW But i did notice that she seemed to talk to me all night like nothing else mattered.  END
BEGIN NOW Then it was six and the sun was coming up.  END
BEGIN NOW So i said it was time for me to leave.  END
BEGIN NOW She got up as well.  END
BEGIN NOW We waited outside for her cab.  END
BEGIN NOW It was cold so i held her close and rubbed her back to keep her warm.  END
BEGIN NOW Then she looked up.  END
BEGIN NOW She looked up into my eyes.  END
BEGIN NOW And we kissed.  END
BEGIN NOW Then her cab came.  END
BEGIN NOW I asked if she wanted to stay the night.  END
BEGIN NOW She said no and jumped in her cab and off to her own bed.  END
BEGIN NOW I bought some orange juice and went home.  END
BEGIN NOW A few days passed.  END
BEGIN NOW I worked in the kitchen and did my job and time flew by.  END
BEGIN NOW Then one night, before she left, Nikki handed me a slip of paper.  END
BEGIN NOW she said, “And this is for you.” and walked away.  END
BEGIN NOW She gave me her number.  END
BEGIN NOW I held that in my pocket for a good hour before i started sending her messeges.  END
BEGIN NOW She texted me back.  END
BEGIN NOW It was that kind of giddy, heart racing sort of thing.  END
BEGIN NOW This went on for several days.  END
BEGIN NOW Then there was a night.  END
BEGIN NOW I was closing the restaurant and Nikki was the closing server.  END
BEGIN NOW She asked if i wanted to get a drink when i got out.  END
BEGIN NOW I said yes of course.  END
BEGIN NOW I got out at one in the morning.  END
BEGIN NOW I had to sous vide a stack of pork bellies.  END
BEGIN NOW it took a while to get everything worked out.  END
BEGIN NOW When i made it to the bar, Nikki was hanging out with Ben, who was very drunk and going through some kind of crisis.  END
BEGIN NOW I joined them and listened to Ben talk about this and that and it was mostly a lot of drunken rambling.  END
BEGIN NOW The Domestication of Shun Feng END
BEGIN NOW I met her in late 2007.  END
BEGIN NOW I remember it being around thanksgiving.  END
BEGIN NOW Certainly before Christmas.  END
BEGIN NOW The exact date and time have long since vanished from memory.  END
BEGIN NOW Almost everything else about her hasn’t.  END
BEGIN NOW She was and is a pastry chef.  END
BEGIN NOW Her given name, the one her family calls her, means ship leaving harbor.  END
BEGIN NOW I should have known then that it would impossible to ever keep her around for long.  END
BEGIN NOW I had just moved to the bay area and was trying out at a new job.  END
BEGIN NOW Working next to her as the pantry cook.  END
BEGIN NOW My world was salads and long wooden platters of sliced meats and cheeses.  END
BEGIN NOW Hers was a world of sugar, confections, cakes and gelato.  END
BEGIN NOW I remember distinctly a kind of nervous energy between us.  END
BEGIN NOW Like when you meet someone and you don’t really make too much eye contact because you might get lost.  END
BEGIN NOW You might forget what you were doing.  END
BEGIN NOW it might unsettle your brain a little.  END
BEGIN NOW I did what i could not to think about it.  END
BEGIN NOW The job i had left in Santa Cruz was my life for two years.  END
BEGIN NOW The chef was a crazy, crack smoking alcoholic.  END
BEGIN NOW His sous chef wasn’t far behind.  END
BEGIN NOW The owner bounced checks and spent all day, everyday drinking his inventory.  END
BEGIN NOW The servers were all girls in their twenties.  END
BEGIN NOW Mostly fresh from college or finishing up their degrees in art history or agriculture.  END
BEGIN NOW They were all very pretty and silly and we all spent a lot of time together in a very small manic restaurant in a back alley behind the movie theater.  END
BEGIN NOW There was one girl in particular, that ruined me for a little while.  END
BEGIN NOW Later on, ruined me much worse.  END
BEGIN NOW But that’s another story for another time.  END
BEGIN NOW I came to the bay area with hopes of a fresh start.  END
BEGIN NOW Away from the drugs and the futility of chasing a skirt that was stuck in an empty relationship.  END
BEGIN NOW I was going to keep my head down, do my job, pay my rent and disregard everything else for a while.  END
BEGIN NOW a kind of autumnal cleansing.  END
BEGIN NOW That didn’t last very long.  END
BEGIN NOW maybe a week. END
BEGIN NOW The first thing i remember about Shun Feng was her cookies.  END
BEGIN NOW The night i was trying out the job, the restaurant was doing a special dinner and she made peanut butter bacon fat cookies shaped like little pigs.  END
BEGIN NOW She came flying back into the kitchen later in the evening to check on her assistant.  END
BEGIN NOW To check her cookies and check her assistant and see just how everything was going for the rest of the kitchen.  END
BEGIN NOW I don’t think she said much to me.  END
BEGIN NOW Or maybe she didn’t say anything that night.  END
BEGIN NOW But there was a moment when our eyes met and a knowing look crossed our faces.  END
BEGIN NOW That uh oh look.  END
BEGIN NOW Like, we’re both in trouble now.  END
BEGIN NOW Nothing has happened but this isn’t going to be ok for anyone involved.  END
BEGIN NOW I ended up getting the job, which paid terribly.  END
BEGIN NOW It was enough to keep enough bourbon in my system and a few cans of cheap beer around the apartment.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes not enough to afford more than rolling tobacco.  END
BEGIN NOW I took home chicken carcasses from the restaurant and made soup.  END
BEGIN NOW We ate a lot of chicken soup and black beans with pasta.  END
BEGIN NOW We were poor but it was always just enough to not feel it too much. END
BEGIN NOW When i saw her again and we had to introduce ourselves she told me, “hi.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m Leslie.  END
BEGIN NOW I’ve been pooping funny, lately.” I don’t remember what i said exactly.  END
BEGIN NOW But it was probably nothing noteworthy.  END
BEGIN NOW i was still lying to myself then.  END
BEGIN NOW Thinking i could do my job, ignore everything else and get on with my life.  END
BEGIN NOW Leslie, i found out, was two years older than me.  END
BEGIN NOW Made really good gelato.  END
BEGIN NOW And was married.  END
BEGIN NOW Recently married.  END
BEGIN NOW And i thought, “well, that’s that.” A lot of my thoughts were way off then.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s what you get for being young and thinking.  END
BEGIN NOW I spent a lot of those days getting very drunk.  END
BEGIN NOW Our apartment was near the south Berkeley ghetto, down on Russell and Sacramento.  END
BEGIN NOW My roommate was finishing his english degree at the University and his grandmother was paying his half of the rent.  END
BEGIN NOW The apartment was in her name and i sent her a check every month to cover my expenses.  END
BEGIN NOW Because we were in the ghetto and neither of us had the place in our name, we didn’t care too much what happened to the place.  END
BEGIN NOW We smoked inside, spilled beer all over the hardwood floor.  END
BEGIN NOW Let beans and hot sauce and cheap cheese become part of the oven.  END
BEGIN NOW I had to pass two bars on my way home each night.  END
BEGIN NOW The Acme and The Missouri.  END
BEGIN NOW In those days, there wasn’t much difference.  END
BEGIN NOW The Missouri had a large patio and a pool table.  END
BEGIN NOW The Acme had a pool table.  END
BEGIN NOW You could smoke in the Acme after nine, since the health inspector wasn’t likely to show up.  END
BEGIN NOW There was a glass jug with some mysterious special cocktail that no one ever drank.  END
BEGIN NOW It was a good bar with dim lights and a lot of whiskey.  END
BEGIN NOW The Missouri isn’t much different today.  END
BEGIN NOW I haven’t been very often since then.  END
BEGIN NOW It was our after work bar.  END
BEGIN NOW A watering hole for a lot of the local cooks.  END
BEGIN NOW A lot of things happened at that bar.  END
BEGIN NOW I like to leave it alone. END
BEGIN NOW I’m trying to remember when our first kiss was.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m pretty sure it was on the fourth of july.  END
BEGIN NOW We had gone through several months of flirting and teasing blushing and saying all manner of highly inappropriate things to each other.  END
BEGIN NOW When the fourth came around there was a big party at one of the cooks houses.  END
BEGIN NOW Around Lake Merritt.  END
BEGIN NOW I was on my way when Leslie called.  END
BEGIN NOW She had been drinking early and had a glow about her.  END
BEGIN NOW She waited for me outside.  END
BEGIN NOW When i came up to the place she said, “The neighbors have these fruit trees.” She walked me back to the trees and there was a fence that divided the cooks yard from us.  END
BEGIN NOW She lured me into her trap.  END
BEGIN NOW As soon as we were out of view she pushed me against the fence and put her mouth on mine.  END
BEGIN NOW Months of pent up sexual tension.  END
BEGIN NOW Weeks on weeks of little flutters of feelings.  END
BEGIN NOW And just like that.  END
BEGIN NOW It exploded.  END
BEGIN NOW She pushed me against the fence and kissed me.  END
BEGIN NOW She kissed me in a way that suggested she was starving, dehydrated.  END
BEGIN NOW And she just found a table laden with food and drink.  END
BEGIN NOW She kissed me like all the fireworks in Chinatown simultaneously erupting in a fountain of floral colors.  END
BEGIN NOW Then i kissed her back.  END
BEGIN NOW Then i knew i was gone.  END
BEGIN NOW We made it to the party and i started drinking and smoking with everyone.  END
BEGIN NOW Eating the kind of old fashion barbecue food that cooks and chefs love more than most things.  END
BEGIN NOW We all got drunk and sang along to songs on the stereo and when the sun went down we lit fireworks and walked down to the lake to watch the real fireworks.  END
BEGIN NOW Not that what we burned wasn’t real.  END
BEGIN NOW But the big showstopper fireworks that you can feel the force of the explosion were over the lake.  END
BEGIN NOW We went back to the house and drank more and sang more and then it was time to go because Leslie was leaving i asked her for a ride. END
BEGIN NOW During the ride i must have tried to kiss her again about a dozen times.  END
BEGIN NOW I was very drunk.  END
BEGIN NOW I didn’t understand that what was ok a few hours ago wasn’t as ok now.  END
BEGIN NOW She pulled up to my apartment and in one swift motion, unclicked my seat belt, opened the passenger door and pushed me out on the curb while she was pulling away.  END
BEGIN NOW Apparently, the way to my heart is riddled with abuse.  END
BEGIN NOW After that, there’s a spot of blur.  END
BEGIN NOW I got promoted to grill cook.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes i had to work brunch.  END
BEGIN NOW We played the kiss off as nothing to worry about for a little bit.  END
BEGIN NOW I think we did.  END
BEGIN NOW I know we were both really bad about pretending there was nothing going on.  END
BEGIN NOW Then there was a particularly brutal brunch.  END
BEGIN NOW I just remember wave after wave of burgers.  END
BEGIN NOW Eight back on eight back on eight.  END
BEGIN NOW for four straight hours.  END
BEGIN NOW My hungover face dripping sweat into the wood burning grill.  END
BEGIN NOW My arms getting more crisscrossed with burn scars by the minute.  END
BEGIN NOW Spatula in one hand, tongs in the other.  END
BEGIN NOW And plate after plate.  END
BEGIN NOW When it was over, i wanted a drink and a cigarette.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s all i could think about.  END
BEGIN NOW I cleaned my station.  END
BEGIN NOW Prepped for the evening and clocked out.  END
BEGIN NOW I walked to the hotel bar because it was still early.  END
BEGIN NOW I like hotel bars because there’s a very different vibe.  END
BEGIN NOW People coming and going.  END
BEGIN NOW Almost no locals.  END
BEGIN NOW You don’t run into people that know you at a hotel bar.  END
BEGIN NOW I wasn’t in a mood for talking.  END
BEGIN NOW I drank four bourbon and sodas.  END
BEGIN NOW I hadn’t eaten all day.  END

BEGIN NOW In an abandoned hotel in a small Romanian town there’s a group of ten young men huddled around screens propped up on old wooden tables from the soviet era.  END
BEGIN NOW The electricity has been rigged from the city's power grid, they guy that did the wiring worked for the city, he wasn’t that expensive to get the job done.  END
BEGIN NOW The internet connection was much the same story.  END
BEGIN NOW These government workers were a lot cheaper these days.  END
BEGIN NOW Greasing palms would get you a blind eye and as good a wiring job as you could get. END
BEGIN NOW The crowd is all young men, most of them self educated.  END
BEGIN NOW Thanks to getting internet access, a lot of them dropped out of school and learned on their own.  END
BEGIN NOW And because it was so easy, many of them took to running scams as a part time, and very lucrative job.  END
BEGIN NOW Fraud is a lot easier when you don’t have to show your face.  END
BEGIN NOW Even easier still when everything you need to know to run the scam is already a few searches away.  END
BEGIN NOW It takes about twenty minutes on average to get to know someone online.  END
BEGIN NOW You can find address, phone number, friends, relatives, job history, education.  END
BEGIN NOW Some of that information has been cataloged by companies that needed to.  END
BEGIN NOW The rest we provided.  END
BEGIN NOW Signing up for accounts that have public displays.  END
BEGIN NOW It all gets cataloged.  END
BEGIN NOW and it’s all so easy to find. END
BEGIN NOW Different scams required different approaches and types of information.  END
BEGIN NOW The easiest and most common was to exploit sexual appetites and loneliness.  END
BEGIN NOW The scammers would pose as women who often had recently lost a loved one.  END
BEGIN NOW They would provide pictures copied from revenge porn sites, where ex-boyfriends post pictures and video of some girl that broke up with them.  END
BEGIN NOW Take that, some sad backstory, and you’d have men all over the world sending you money for plane tickets, for funeral expenses, for buying a new watch, a new car, whatever you wanted.  END
BEGIN NOW It was too easy.  END
BEGIN NOW They would sit in internet cafes and chat up other men across the globe, squeezing out a few dollars here and there and occasionally a large sum.  END
BEGIN NOW When they wanted to know what became of their little investment, something would always come up.  END
BEGIN NOW Some of these men would be strung along for years.  END
BEGIN NOW Others, it was just a grab and go.  END
BEGIN NOW They would be too embarrassed to report anything.  END
BEGIN NOW Most of them had wives.  END
BEGIN NOW It wouldn’t look good that they lost a few thousand dollars to support some poor girl in Syria.  END
BEGIN NOW Sure, you could make it look like charity, but that was always a stretch. END
BEGIN NOW That was always how it started with this crowd.  END
BEGIN NOW Then they would learn more advanced forms of phishing.  END
BEGIN NOW Phishing takes the ‘ph’ in its name from the old phone phreaks.  END
BEGIN NOW The basic idea behind phishing is that you coerce people into giving up information by making yourself look like a credible source.  END
BEGIN NOW They had tools to clone a website, making you think you were logging into your bank or your email.  END
BEGIN NOW They had a dummy server set up that will log your credentials, then send you off to the real site saying that the password was incorrect, please try again.  END
BEGIN NOW in the mean time, they had a database full of usernames and passwords for your bank account.  END
BEGIN NOW The system was very simple. END
BEGIN NOW Collect as many email address as possible.  END
BEGIN NOW Clone an email from the bank so that all the text and graphics look exactly like the real thing.  END
BEGIN NOW Tell the customer that they found something on their account requires their immediate attention, have them click a link from the email to the dummy server, they log in, it doesn’t work, they log in again, and everything appears normal.  END
BEGIN NOW Little do they know, they’ve given everything away.  END
BEGIN NOW And over in Romainia and the Ukraine, and Nigeria, someone is harvesting that information, reselling it, or siphoning money from it to a private account somewhere else. END
BEGIN NOW They developed what they call spear phishing, which is where you target an individual, or small group of individuals.  END
BEGIN NOW Say you wanted to get access to a company’s server.  END
BEGIN NOW You go over to LinkedIn, find the company and harvest all the email addresses attached to that company.  END
BEGIN NOW If you’re running linux, you can download a script that will do this for you.  END
BEGIN NOW Next, forge an email from the system administrator saying that something is going down, or some system needs to be reconfigured and everyone needs to go reset their passwords.  END
BEGIN NOW You clone the company pages, figure out what software they use for all this, easily done with a few searches or spidering the company website, and set up a duplicate site that is on your own server.  END
BEGIN NOW Most people won’t know the difference and just click away because it’s their job.  END
BEGIN NOW Because they're used to it.  END
BEGIN NOW and it’s just another hassle from the IT department. END
BEGIN NOW After that, you have access.  END
BEGIN NOW From their it’s a matter of escalating privilege.  END
BEGIN NOW This is accomplished by either exploiting a bug in the software that will break and transfer you over to an administrative account, or most of the time, that information is already there, you just need to find it.  END
BEGIN NOW Once found, most of these credentials are encrypted and the average person thinks, great, case closed.  END
BEGIN NOW Not the case by a long shot.  END
BEGIN NOW If you’re no good at picking a password, it’ll take between one and fifteen minutes to crack the code.  END
BEGIN NOW If you’re smarter, it could take a few days.  END
BEGIN NOW If you’re really clever, if will take much too long and the attacker will likely give up.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes an encrypted password can take years.  END
BEGIN NOW The way it works is like this, you have a password, let's say it’s ‘vanilla’ when you enter that password into a computer it runs it through a very complicated bit of math called an algorithm.  END
BEGIN NOW This takes ‘vanilla’ and turns it into ‘e8228fbca27926470a009c04a6af6df5’.  END
BEGIN NOW (that’s an MD5 hash, if you want to know the algorithm.) The math is such that simply reversing it is impossible.  END
BEGIN NOW So what the clever code breakers figured out was that we can take a list of words, run it through the same algorithm until we get a match.  END
BEGIN NOW With a modern computer this can take little more than seconds for a word like ‘vanilla’.  END
BEGIN NOW However, if your password was ‘I like vanilla ice cream’ it will take much longer.  END
BEGIN NOW The reason being that phrases are not listed in a word file.  END
BEGIN NOW And having a list of phrases would take much longer to figure out and be an extravagantly large file.  END
BEGIN NOW Throw in some symbols and numbers to make, ‘I l1kE v@n1lla Ic3 Cream’ and you have a password that will take years to decrypt.  END
BEGIN NOW Once again, that depends on how fast your computer can translate the words into hashes. END
BEGIN NOW In Romania one of the kids looks up from the group and says, END
BEGIN NOW “I got it.  END
BEGIN NOW I’ve got the hash file.” He smiles a very proud smile.  END
BEGIN NOW One of the other kids goes to a cooler and gets a round of beers for everyone.  END
BEGIN NOW From this point most of the process will be automated.  END
BEGIN NOW They’ll split the hash file into workable pieces, and each person will let it run until all the passwords have been recovered.  END

BEGIN NOW He had his winter clothes in a pile, his summer clothes in another pile.  END
BEGIN NOW The laptop he managed to save up for by the head of the mattress.  END

BEGIN NOW This made it even easier to trick people into giving up valuable information.  END

BEGIN NOW The game had changed a lot over the last few years.  END
BEGIN NOW More and more dial-ups were disappearing.  END
BEGIN NOW The networks were all moving to the internet.  END
BEGIN NOW everything was getting more connected.  END
BEGIN NOW All the old phone numbers were being replaced by internet protocol addresses.  END
BEGIN NOW The tools were changing with the territory.  END
BEGIN NOW Sawyer was running a custom linux build.  END
BEGIN NOW He rewrote much of the software, which was also easier now, thanks to the open source movement.  END
BEGIN NOW There were a host of new languages to learn as well.  END
BEGIN NOW He taught himself PERL and HTML rather quickly.  END
BEGIN NOW The migration over to internet also meant that targets were more varied.  END
BEGIN NOW He wasn’t limited to anything in his area code anymore.  END
BEGIN NOW He could dial up one of the service providers and from there poke around networks on the east coast, or the midwest or the south.  END
BEGIN NOW or Europe.  END
BEGIN NOW or Russia.  END
BEGIN NOW Funny thing about computers, no matter what language you speak, you have to write code in english.  END

BEGIN NOW No one thought it was just the quiet guy next door.  END
BEGIN NOW It wasn’t until digital forensics went through their router logs and noticed repeated late night connections from a MAC address that didn’t belong to anyone in the house.  END
BEGIN NOW That’s when they figured out that their WiFi was hacked. END
BEGIN NOW Here’s the funny thing about MAC addresses.  END
BEGIN NOW Every device has one, and each one is unique.  END
BEGIN NOW they have a format that looks like: 20:E5:2A:5E:12:37 the first half will delineate the manufacturer, the second half will identify the make and model.  END
BEGIN NOW The problem is that changing this for most devices is a process that takes at most, a few minutes.  END
BEGIN NOW you can make it so that your router identifies as an iPhone, or your iPhone identifies as smart TV.  END
BEGIN NOW Or you can make up a number as long as it follows the xx:xx:xx:yy:yy:yy format.  END
BEGIN NOW The number set is in hexadecimal you have values ranging from 0-F where F=15.  END
BEGIN NOW This gives us 281,474,976,710,656 possible combinations.  END
BEGIN NOW We’re at a point in history where we’re running out of available addresses, so they’re extended the format.  END
BEGIN NOW The main point of his rabbit trail is two fold.  END
BEGIN NOW A search and a little bit of know how means any device can masquerade as any other device.  END
BEGIN NOW The other thing to keep in mind is there are security measures that require connected devices to have certain MAC addresses.  END
BEGIN NOW The problem is, those addresses are broadcasted to the public.  END
BEGIN NOW Let’s say, for instance, you’re running a private network at your place of business.  END
BEGIN NOW You’ve setup your WiFi to filter out approved MAC addresses, thinking that anyone with an unregistered device won’t be able to get in.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m an attacker, using only my cell phone, I can sweep the radio signal and every device will bounce back with information including the device name, MAC address, IP, and possibly more.  END
BEGIN NOW I then use a bit of software to change my MAC address to one that’s already connected to your network.  END
BEGIN NOW The router sees the same address, says right this way sir, and I’m in.  END
BEGIN NOW If i need the password to the WiFi as well, that will take at most another thirty minutes.  END
BEGIN NOW If i have a laptop, maybe less.  END
BEGIN NOW If i’m a social engineer, it will take a phone call.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m enjoying these tangents of explaining security things.  END
BEGIN NOW It helps me remember how much i know and gets me to research what I don’t.  END
BEGIN NOW they can also be very distracting.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes i’ll start looking up something and hours later i’ll be running subnet scans and trying to find vulnerabilities.  END
BEGIN NOW the thrill of the hunt is slow and methodical.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s an interesting time we live in, when we have hackers that are actively working against, working with, and working for the governments of the world.  END
BEGIN NOW There’s hackers that made a legitimate business out of it.  END
BEGIN NOW And many more that made a less than legitimate business.  END
BEGIN NOW In addition to all the old tricks, we now have ransomware, which is truly sinister.  END
BEGIN NOW One wrong click and all of your data, your entire computer is encrypted with someone else's key.  END
BEGIN NOW And the only way to get it back, if you don’t have backups, is to pay up.  END
BEGIN NOW We have ways to put invisible frames into web pages, luring victims to click on things they can’t even see, in turn giving the attacker tokens that allow them to masquerade as the victim.  END
BEGIN NOW It goes so much deeper than just passwords and usernames.  END
BEGIN NOW Looking back at the TalkTalk breach from last month, when a couple of kids managed to leak the user database of a large telecom company.  END
BEGIN NOW And they did it by executing a single command.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes, that’s all it takes.  END

BEGIN NOW We think of the cloud as a kind of ethereal concept where data lives.  END
BEGIN NOW The reality of the cloud is more like a large room full of rack mount servers.  END
BEGIN NOW Picture a cage like locker room with climate controls and lots of blinking LEDs.  END
BEGIN NOW Wires criss-crossing each other in zip tied clusters, each one with a label.  END
BEGIN NOW The room is always under lock and key with cameras point at every entrance and exit.  END
BEGIN NOW We like to think of the cloud as a giant hard drive that floats in the aether.  END
BEGIN NOW We like to think that everything that goes into the cloud is safe and untouchable.  END
BEGIN NOW This of course isn’t true at all.  END
BEGIN NOW There’s a thousand ways in.  END
BEGIN NOW Most of them are walking around with name tags.  END
BEGIN NOW The weakest link is and always will be other people.  END
BEGIN NOW And the easiest way to utilize them is to exploit their curiosity and their trust.  END
BEGIN NOW This can be accomplished in a manner of different ways.  END
BEGIN NOW I think we covered phishing and spear phishing earlier, so we’re going to take a different approach this time. END
BEGIN NOW Our friends in Romania have some splinter groups or factions or friends.  END
BEGIN NOW People all around the world near various facilities, waiting for orders.  END
BEGIN NOW One foot solider is given marching orders for a data center in Maryland.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s going to try a tried and true method of breaking into the place without setting foot in the door.  END
BEGIN NOW He goes to his local office supply store and buys a box of low capacity USB keys.  END
BEGIN NOW The rest of the process is a little meticulous if he hadn’t written scripts to accomplish it.  END
BEGIN NOW He reformats all the keys and adds some code to the partition that is fired up whenever the key is inserted into a machine.  END
BEGIN NOW He has that code check for the make and model of the machine, what kind of operating system is running, then it will trigger another script.  END
BEGIN NOW The second script will find a process is each type of common computer on the market and latch onto it.  END
BEGIN NOW It will create a backdoor that calls back to his computer at home and the group in Romania.  END
BEGIN NOW It won’t have low level privilege, but it will be an in.  END
BEGIN NOW It’ll be a start.  END
BEGIN NOW From there, they can escalate and infiltrate. END
BEGIN NOW Our guy on the ground takes handfuls of these USB keys and leaves them in the parking lot.  END
BEGIN NOW He tails a few employees on lunch break to see where they go.  END
BEGIN NOW He leaves a key or two near their car.  END
BEGIN NOW Making it look like they must have dropped it.  END
BEGIN NOW He peppers every place he thinks someone that works at the data center might look.  END
BEGIN NOW Once he gets a hit, he has his home system pick up the connection and automatically work from there.  END
BEGIN NOW For every hit he gets, a message pops up on his phone with the address of the compromised system and any information his scripts have gathered so far.  END
BEGIN NOW If something really good comes up, he rushes home and takes over the autopilot.  END
BEGIN NOW He keeps track for his own records and logs and to make sure his employers across the sea get what they pay for.  END
BEGIN NOW He’s very good at his job.  END
BEGIN NOW The lost USB key method has a 75% chance of success.  END
BEGIN NOW Variations of this method include going up to the front desk and saying you found this outside and it probably belongs to someone.  END
BEGIN NOW Or handing out CDs on the street.  END
BEGIN NOW Or sending it via the post with a priority envelope and a return address that makes it seem like official business.  END
BEGIN NOW Even if a person doesn’t recognize the device, more often than not, they want to know what’s on the disk.  END
BEGIN NOW To minimize the failure rate, our guy has coded some juicy looking stuff to pop up and distract who ever was curious.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes it’s some amatur pornography, sometimes it’s leaked company documents.  END
BEGIN NOW Sometimes it’s a game, or some music.  END
BEGIN NOW He tries to play it by ear, depending on who the target is.  END
BEGIN NOW Some of you might be thinking, i’ve got an anti-virus set up that will detect these types of trojans.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m totally safe and secure.  END
BEGIN NOW Well, I’m sorry, but no.  END
BEGIN NOW The code for the payload is what your antivirus is looking for.  END
BEGIN NOW Usually a very specific few lines of code, like scanning for a signature.  END
BEGIN NOW The clever attacker has a piece of software on his side that will run that signiture through a kind of sausage grinder, usually multiple times, making it look nothing like the original.  END
BEGIN NOW The anti-virus has no idea what it’s looking and at and passes it along, thinking that everything is going just fine.  END
BEGIN NOW The effort it takes to do this is minimal.  END
BEGIN NOW The time it takes is fifteen minutes or less. END

BEGIN NOW On November 2nd, 1988 the world of computer security changed forever.  END
BEGIN NOW You might even say that the idea of needing computer security really started on that day.  END
BEGIN NOW At least the public awareness of how vulnerable this project, later known as the internet, really was.  END
BEGIN NOW A few days before his 23rd birthday, a student near MIT released a project he’d been working on that was going to try to map every connected UNIX machine in the world.  END
BEGIN NOW He knew of a few vulnerabilities in the sendmail program that was standard, along with a handful of other services and a bunch of default passwords.  END
BEGIN NOW The program would jump from machine to machine, replicating and looking for every host the computer was connected to.  END
BEGIN NOW It was supposed to harmlessly travel and catalog every host that it found.  END
BEGIN NOW Due to a small programming error, it reproduced out of control, crippling every machine it came into contact with.  END
BEGIN NOW Within a few hours 20,000 computers were infected.  END
BEGIN NOW this was the first instance of what became known as the Morris Worm.  END
BEGIN NOW The fallout took days to recover, with teams working around the clock to isolate and remove the worm.  END
BEGIN NOW Normal maintenance wouldn’t work, the worm just crawled back in.  END
BEGIN NOW For more information, see Clifford Stoll’s fantastic book, The Cuckoo’s Nest (1989). END
BEGIN NOW The real damage from the Morris Worm, as is the case with many new and fascinating crimes, are the copy cats.  END
BEGIN NOW With a good programmer, all you really need is the idea.  END
BEGIN NOW Figuring out how to execute the idea is half the fun.  END
BEGIN NOW Debugging isn’t as much, but the thrill of working on something for months and seeing a successful run through is a very unique kind of rush.  END
BEGIN NOW The idea of coding multiple viruses together, making it replicate and spread, and it some cases, adapt to various circumstances, has a wide appeal.  END
BEGIN NOW All you need is the idea.  END
BEGIN NOW Sawyer’s idea was grand in scale.  END
BEGIN NOW It was all at once, elegant, sinister, devastating, and beautiful.  END

BEGIN NOW Deep in his basement prison cell, Sawyer knew something was very wrong when the food stopped coming.  END
BEGIN NOW The power flickered every now and again, another cause for concern.  END
BEGIN NOW He figured, after three days, that it was now or never. END
BEGIN NOW Phase one of the worm would take out all the surveillance in the building and anything attached to the same network.  END
BEGIN NOW It was not the sneaky kind of taking out the surveillance popular in movies and television where the crafty thieves loop footage on all the cameras so that no one suspects a thing.  END
BEGIN NOW This worm just knocked it right out.  END
BEGIN NOW erased everything.  END
BEGIN NOW The footage, the software, the firmware, the drivers. END
BEGIN NOW Phase two would disable all door locks, all security systems, and clog the phone systems.  END
BEGIN NOW He didn’t have a radio jammer, so taking out any communications beyond the phone lines was impossible.  END
BEGIN NOW He would have to make due.  END
BEGIN NOW That should be enough to get him out of the building. END
BEGIN NOW Phase three was coded to get into the outside world.  END
BEGIN NOW Phase three had the goal of ruining his old partner, Carter.  END
BEGIN NOW The worm would shift Carter’s finances to some shady and illegal operations.  END
BEGIN NOW Lots of drug money on the dark web, frame him in with some cartels, make it international.  END
BEGIN NOW After the money looked like it was going to some criminal places he would leak the story to every news outlet, every blog, twitter feed.  END
BEGIN NOW Carter’s reputation would be shot in the course of several minutes.  END
BEGIN NOW The worm would make it look like a classic slip up.  END
BEGIN NOW Letting some personal data go unencrypted on the dark web on an exit node that was owned by the cops.  END
BEGIN NOW He was pretty sure that the feds were already watching Carter very closely.  END
BEGIN NOW He was sure that they’d be at his door soon and having him in a nicely wrapped package of evidence land on their digital doorstep would only help them out.  END
BEGIN NOW Sure, it would look like a classic betrayal situation, but the feds didn’t care.  END
BEGIN NOW It was more leverage. END

BEGIN NOW “MR. PRESIDENT!” END
BEGIN NOW The most powerful man in the world was asleep on his sleeve, his suit wrinkled and his face wrinkled and his spirit soaked in spirits.  END
BEGIN NOW He roused from his substance induced slumber and cracked a bloodshot eye at the aide that entered his chambers deep underground below the white house.  END
BEGIN NOW HIs private bunker built during the second world war, strong enough to withstand a nuclear blast.  END

BEGIN NOW He felt helpless and angry.  END

BEGIN NOW If only he could go back in time and stop this mess before it started.  END
BEGIN NOW This was no time to live in regrets. END

BEGIN NOW “Thompson, sir.” END
BEGIN NOW “Thompson, right.  END
BEGIN NOW what’s the latest from the surface?” END

BEGIN NOW The streets are clogged with dissent and they want to hear from you.  END
BEGIN NOW I suspect they want your head.” END
BEGIN NOW “That’s great.  END
BEGIN NOW Great news.” The president looked around his desk for something to drink.  END
BEGIN NOW A bottle of painkillers, some stimulants to balance out the opiates.  END
BEGIN NOW Anything to kick his brain into working for a little while longer.  END
BEGIN NOW His hairs were greying rapidly.  END
BEGIN NOW He had aged more in the last few days than most presidents do during their whole term.  END
BEGIN NOW He was, over all things, a very tired man. END
BEGIN NOW “Thompson, do we have anything left to drink is this hell hole?” END
BEGIN NOW “Yes, sir.” Thompson exited the room and returned with a jug of ice water and a decanter of brown liquid. END
BEGIN NOW “That’s spirit.  END
BEGIN NOW that’s why i wanted you here.  END
BEGIN NOW No messing around.  END
BEGIN NOW You’re a good man, Thompson.” END
BEGIN NOW “Thank you, sir.” END
BEGIN NOW “glasses!” END
BEGIN NOW “Yes, sir.” END
BEGIN NOW The president poured them both three fingers of the brown liquor. END
BEGIN NOW “Cheers,” Mr. President said, “To the end of the civilized world.” He downed the whole glass and filled it again.  END
BEGIN NOW Thompson took a liberal gulp and eyed the president wearily. END
BEGIN NOW “How goes progress with operation payback?” END
BEGIN NOW “The strike was ordered to execute at 2200 hours.  END
BEGIN NOW We’re awaiting confirmation of destruction, sir.” END
BEGIN NOW “Excellent, that’s great news.” END

BEGIN NOW “Roger, Angel of Death target is approaching, ready when you are.” END

BEGIN NOW on my count, fire.” END

BEGIN NOW 2.  END
BEGIN NOW 1.  END
BEGIN NOW Fire!” END

BEGIN NOW The bombs point straight down.  END
BEGIN NOW The bunker buster is a bomb designed to penetrate concrete up to several meters before detonating.  END

BEGIN NOW The world was plunged into a kind of chaos unknown for generations.  END
BEGIN NOW it was a wonder that some people felt compelled to try to keep things running.  END
BEGIN NOW The mail was one of those things.  END
BEGIN NOW Nor rain nor snow nor sleet nor hail nor revolution nor eroded faith in the powers that be.  END
BEGIN NOW The military had been called in to restore order while the president hid away in his bunker, engaged in his own war with his liver.  END
BEGIN NOW His wife and children were being kept away from him.  END
BEGIN NOW Thompson was the only person he allowed into his office.  END
BEGIN NOW Even then it was only to drink, mostly in silence.  END
BEGIN NOW He would ask on occasion about the situation on the surface.  END
BEGIN NOW The news was never what he wanted to hear.  END

BEGIN NOW The sour looks of his diplomatic advisor.  END
BEGIN NOW The constant aggression of his military man.  END

BEGIN NOW He missed the good old days.  END
BEGIN NOW And he drank, waiting for the storm to pass and some semblance of order to be restored. END
BEGIN NOW Sawyer had managed to loot a few tools.  END
BEGIN NOW He found a working cell phone.  END
BEGIN NOW He found a place that hadn’t been fire bombed by the angry public, enough for him to plug in and see how far his revenge worm had gotten.  END
BEGIN NOW Not far enough after the banks collapsed.  END
BEGIN NOW Not as far as he was hoping.  END
BEGIN NOW He looked everywhere for signs that his old friend was active somewhere, but was coming up empty.  END
BEGIN NOW Figures.  END
BEGIN NOW He no doubt had a backup plan in case of this kind of scenario.  END

BEGIN NOW Sawyer found a place to camp out near his old P.O.  END
BEGIN NOW Box, in hopes that his new identity would arrive and his money would follow.  END

BEGIN NOW “No need to run, boy.  END

BEGIN NOW have a beer, they’re still cold.” END

BEGIN NOW His world was lies and deception.  END
BEGIN NOW trust was a vulnerability waiting to be exploited. END

BEGIN NOW The capitals across the country were surrounded by mobs of people camping out.  END
BEGIN NOW Everyone was waiting for a leader.  END
BEGIN NOW Everyone was getting restless.  END
BEGIN NOW The energy that fueled the revolution was dying off and most people were returning to their homes, trying to figure out what to do next.  END
BEGIN NOW The rest, the politically minded, the ones that believed in a system of functioning government, camped out, looking for guidance on the next move.  END
BEGIN NOW in situations where people are looking for a leader, it’s assured that someone, usually severally people, will think they know what’s best for everyone.  END

BEGIN NOW the old city halls and courtrooms were filled again.  END

BEGIN NOW slowly taking back the city from the revolutionaries.  END

BEGIN NOW That the people in charge were promising paychecks from banks that no longer existed.  END
BEGIN NOW It didn’t take long for them to take their issued rifles and go find a shelter or a plot of land and call it their own. END

BEGIN NOW Means the world to me.” END

BEGIN NOW I am a very tired man.” END
BEGIN NOW “Yes, sir.” Thompson was tired too.  END
BEGIN NOW He felt it wasn’t appropriate to admit this to the most powerful man in the world.  END
BEGIN NOW He wanted to be tough until the end. END
BEGIN NOW “I..  END
BEGIN NOW think… i’m just gonna..  END
BEGIN NOW lay down for a bit.” END
BEGIN NOW “As you wish, sir.” Thompson refilled his glass and drank it down, no longer feeling the burn, not really feeling anything except an empty splash in his guts. END
BEGIN NOW The president slumped off his chair and landed on the rug, soiled with spills and ashes.  END
BEGIN NOW Mr. President curled into the fetal position and began snoring loudly.  END
BEGIN NOW Thompson walked over to the flag hanging proudly from the pole.  END

BEGIN NOW He walked over to the president humming the national anthem.  END
BEGIN NOW With the greatest care he draped the flag over the president’s sleeping body.  END
BEGIN NOW Thompson sat back down in his chair in front of the presidential desk.  END
BEGIN NOW He poured himself a long drink.  END
BEGIN NOW and polished off the bottle.  END
BEGIN NOW He took a long look at the great seal of the United States.  END
BEGIN NOW He looked at the majesty of the Eagle.  END
BEGIN NOW He was feeling sick and a little dizzy.  END
BEGIN NOW The room was gearing up to spin around him.  END
BEGIN NOW He put the glass to his lips and looked down at the sleeping, snoring figure of the most powerful man in the world.  END
BEGIN NOW He closed his eyes and tilted his head back, taking the last gulp of brown liquor, letting it hit him in his rapidly deteriorating guts.  END
BEGIN NOW He put the glass down on the desk, stiffened his back and gave a salute.  END

BEGIN NOW Author’s final note.  END
BEGIN NOW Epilogue. END
BEGIN NOW So, that’s it.  END
BEGIN NOW I made my goal with time to spare.  END
BEGIN NOW this may be a first for me.  END
BEGIN NOW And were i not lazy and skipped some days that i was perfectly capable of getting some writing done, or distracted by whatever, I probably could have doubled the word count.  END
BEGIN NOW Too many days were spent going, well, i hit 1666.  END
BEGIN NOW that’s over with.  END
BEGIN NOW Despite all of that, one thing did happen that I am happy about.  END
BEGIN NOW writing 5k today was a fairly painless experience.  END
BEGIN NOW It was actually, one of the easiest days i had writing this big ol’ blob of shit.  END
BEGIN NOW And if anything, that’s how it should be.  END
BEGIN NOW I had something of an ending in mind.  END
BEGIN NOW And I’m pretty ok with how everything turned out.  END
BEGIN NOW Sawyer meets the bums.  END
BEGIN NOW Carter has disappeared.  END
BEGIN NOW The world is a mess and is trying to fix itself the only way it knows how.  END
BEGIN NOW With more violence and the same old tired politics.  END
BEGIN NOW It’s a pretty good nobody wins situation.  END
BEGIN NOW I haven’t read back through anything.  END
BEGIN NOW And i’m going to give it a few days before i do.  END
BEGIN NOW The idea of completion, in some sense, has been achieved.  END
BEGIN NOW I do feel that overall, I set out to do this and I did it.  END
BEGIN NOW and that was worth the whole month, The next step is to keep some momentum going.  END
BEGIN NOW to keep improving on writing.  END
BEGIN NOW to get better and re-learn how to actually tell a story that i want to tell.  END
BEGIN NOW Right now i’m tired.  END
BEGIN NOW my brain is operating on a few hours of sleep, my eyes are dry, my throat is dry.  END
BEGIN NOW my sense of humor is dry. END
BEGIN NOW I learned a lot of things this month.  END
BEGIN NOW i learned about the current state of hacking culture and the terrible state that our collective sense of security is in.  END
BEGIN NOW I learned that rushing into a writing project with zero prep and thought going into it except, “I want to write about the new cold war.” wasn’t the best idea.  END
BEGIN NOW And granted, if i took out all the asides and rabbit trails, i’d be hard pressed to hit 25k of actual content.  END
BEGIN NOW of that maybe 10% is probably salvageable.  END
BEGIN NOW But that’s too bad.  END
BEGIN NOW I’m going to keep writing some gibberish until the 12:00 hits.  END
BEGIN NOW Just to add some padding to this nonsense.  END
BEGIN NOW keep the old digits moving.  END
BEGIN NOW Or not.  END
BEGIN NOW I keep getting distracted.  END
BEGIN NOW I guess that’s going to be my new year’s resolution.  END
BEGIN NOW focus on what i’m trying to do.  END
BEGIN NOW And with that, I’m going to put a nail in this project and call it a night.  END
BEGIN NOW Pour myself a stiff drink and bid ye adieu. END
